The SPEAKER ( Hon.
Milton Dick ) took the chair at 10:00, made an acknowledgement of country and read prayers.
COMMITTEES
Petitions Committee
Report
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): I present the 13th report of the Petitions Committee for the 47th Parliament.
Chair Ms Susan Templeman MP
Deputy Chair Mr Ross Vasta MP
Mr Sam Birrell MP
Ms Alison Byrnes MP
Ms Lisa Chesters MP
Mr Garth Hamilton MP
Ms Tracy Roberts MP
Ms Meryl Swanson MP

span.span: Report summarising the petitions and ministerial responses being presented.
The committee met in private session in the 47th Parliament on 2 August 2023.
1. The committee resolved to present the following 2 petitions in accordance with standing order 207:

p.span: From 401 petitioners—regarding the undergrounding of power lines in the Apollo Bay network (PN0564)
From 55 petitioners—requesting an end to the indefinite detention of refugees (PN0566)

span.span: 2. The following 81 ministerial responses to petitions were received:
Ministerial responses received by the Committee on 2 August 2023

PETITIONS
Presentation
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): I present the following two petitions:
Energy
This petition draws to the attention of the House the inefficiency of overhead powerlines and how power outages are increasing in number and severity due to ageing electricity grids.
Outages, particularly those related to natural disasters, are almost always accompanied by intersecting events that result in economic, social, environmental and health damages.

There are also many examples where overhead powerlines have caused a natural disaster in Victoria and indeed, Australia, causing subsequent power outages, often for extended periods of time and impacting our communities negatively.
Outages are not inevitable and make us vulnerable, depending on the frequency, duration, timing, and location. Underground power cables are sustainable, reliable, and visually inconspicuous.

We therefore ask the House to ensure that all new cabling in rural and regional areas is installed underground as the default and commit to a program of undergrounding current powerlines with priority given to areas designated as bushfire-prone areas. We also ask that the House commits to a program taking into consideration the contribution of underground cables in mitigating power outages during natural disasters. Consideration must be given to the cost of these supply interruptions for both business and community members. We ask the House to also take into consideration the effect of overhead lines and protect our natural environment for our wildlife and their habitats, and the landscape, including impacts on tourism, liveability, and land values.
from 401 citizens (Petition No. PN0564)
Immigration Detention

For too long, many decades, refugees and asylum seekers who have legally sought refuge in Australia from war and violence, have been forced instead into long-term, indefinite detention, which has seriously affected their health and well-being.
1. We the undersigned humbly petition the Australian Government to end all indefinite offshore and onshore detention of refugees and asylum seekers.
2. We further ask that there be a 90 day time limit for the resolution of visa processing.
3. If this request is not met, after 90 days, all refugees and asylum seekers should be released into the community, with work rights, while awaiting the outcome of their application.
from 55 citizens (Petition No. PN0566)
Petitions received.
PETITIONS
Responses
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): I present the following 81 ministerial responses to petitions previously presented:
Australian Currency
Dear Chair

We thank you for the Standing Committee's correspondence concerning Petition EN2461 on the legalisation of cryptocurrencies. The former Chair's correspondence to the Hon Jane Hume has been referred to me for response.

On 22 August 2022, the Government announced its plan for crypto asset reforms in a media release which can be found on the Treasury website under 'Media Releases'. On 3 February 2023, Treasury released a consultation paper on its token mapping exercise, which can be found on the consultations section of the Treasury website.

The consultation paper explores the legal and regulatory status of the crypto ecosystem in detail. The responses to the consultation paper will inform the Government on the elements of the crypto ecosystem that require additional legal and regulatory attention. The reforms resulting from the token mapping exercise will aim to provide legal and regulatory clarity for crypto service providers and ensure additional safeguards for Australians.

Following the release of the token mapping consultation paper, the Government has been working with Treasury on a custody and licensing framework for crypto service providers. A proposed licensing and custody framework will be subject to a period of public consultation later this year.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer and Minister for Financial Services, Mr Jones
COVID-19: Parliamentarians' Entitlements
Dear Chair

I am writing in relation to correspondence of 21 October 2021 to the former Special Minister of State, the Hon Ben Morton, regarding a petition for the House of Representatives to introduce and approve a bill to cap the income earned by politicians in line with government COVID disaster payments (EN2964). This matter has recently been referred to me to respond.

The pay and allowances for Senators and Members of Parliament are determined by the Remuneration Tribunal (Tribunal), and not by parliamentarians or the Australian Government. The Tribunal is a statutory body and is independent and separate from the Australian Government.

While the matters raised in the petition regarding pay for parliamentarians are for the consideration of the Tribunal, I can advise that the then Government wrote to the Tribunal to request a pause of any pay increases for all senior office holders in its jurisdiction, including parliamentarians, due to the COVID-19 crisis. The Tribunal considered this request when implementing a pause in its determination in 2020.

Further to this, the Tribunal released a statement about its 2021 review of remuneration for holders of public office. In the statement, the Tribunal advised that it decided to make no increases in remuneration for public offices in its jurisdiction, including members of Parliament, from 1 July 2021.

The Tribunal's obligations, under subsections 7(3) and 8(1)(b) of the Remuneration Tribunal Act 1973 and sections 14 and 45 of the Parliamentary Business Resources Act 2017, are to make determinations in respect of remuneration for various offices within its jurisdiction, including parliamentarians, at periods of not more than one year.

In considering whether any adjustment should occur, the Tribunal takes account of economic conditions in Australia, past and projected movements in remuneration in the public and private sectors (including the Australian Public Service), as well as outcomes of reviews of public offices completed by the Tribunal.

Consistent with previous decisions, the Tribunal maintains the view that the pay of parliamentarians should increase relative to that of the pay of other public office holders, and thus the decision to determine no annual adjustment for the office holders in the Tribunal's jurisdiction applied to parliamentarians for the 2020-21 and 2021-22 financial periods.

In 2022, the Tribunal decided to increase remuneration by 2.75 per cent for public offices in its jurisdiction from 1 July 2022. All annual reviews conducted by the Tribunal are publicly available and, in particular, the 2020, 2021 and 2022 Review of Remuneration for Holders of Public Office Statements, which includes parliamentarians, can be found on its website at: www.remtribunal.gov au.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Special Minister of State, Senator Farrell
Electoral Roll
Dear Ms Templeman

On 14 February 2022, your predecessor Mr Ken O'Dowd referred petition EN3598 about voter identification requirements to the former Special Minister of State, the Hon Ben Morton. As this was not responded to during the term of the former Government, I am responding as the current Special Minister of State.

The petition raises concerns about the voter identification provisions proposed under the Electoral Legislation Amendment: (Voter integrity) Bill 2021 (the Bill). The Government opposed the Bill when in opposition and the Bill lapsed at dissolution of the previous Parliament on 11 April 2022. In his second reading speech opposing that Bill, the now Prime Minister, the Hon Anthony Albanese MP, stated that the bill would, "make it harder for Australians to cast their votes".

This Government will continue to oppose voter identification should a similar Bill be brought before the Parliament. The former Government's proposal would have seen Australians without valid identification turned away at the ballot box, voting taking much longer for individuals on the day, and our democracy weakened. There was, and remains, no compelling reason to establish these voter identification laws in Australia.

The Albanese Government is instead committed to removing barriers to participation in democratic processes for all Australians and pursing reforms that make our electoral system fairer, not more inaccessible. This Government follows the legacy of former Labor governments, which have led federal electoral reform in Australian delivering more transparency and accountability. Reforms by the Hawke Labor Government in the 1980s provided the framework for Australia's contemporary elections and our democracy.

Notably, the Hawke Government transformed our democratic institutions with the creation of the independent Australian Electoral Commission to conduct and oversee elections. It also increased transparency by introducing a regime for regulating and disclosing political donations and electoral expenditure. Later, the Gillard Labor Government delivered the direct enrolment program, which continues today using data to help maintain the electoral roll by bringing more Australians onto the electoral roll and updating enrolment details.

Our Government believes a strong democracy depends on all citizens being able to participate equally and we must work to ensure voting is accessible to all through access to enrolment. Earlier this year I approved regulatory changes to increase access to enrolment for eligible Australians. This change expanded the forms of identification a voter can use to enrol or update their enrolment to include Medicare and Australian citizenship notice numbers. This will further support those citizens who previously faced barriers to enrolment because they did not have an Australian driver's license or passport to participate in elections and referendums.

The Albanese Government continues to work to further strengthen our electoral system. To this end, I have asked the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters to initiate an inquiry into the 2022 Federal Election. Amongst other significant issues for investigation, I requested that part of the Committee's considerations include ways to encourage increased electoral participation and support enfranchisement generally. I look forward to receiving the Committee's recommendations and its progress can be followed here: www.aph.gov.au/Parliamentary_Business/Committees/Joint/Electoral_Matters.

As part of this Government's commitment to implement the Uluru Statement from the Heart, a referendum will be held between October and December 2023 to recognise Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples in the Constitution by establishing an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice. Within my responsibilities for electoral matters, I have already ensured the referendum machinery legislation is up-to-date, so that the referendum reflects contemporary electoral practises, including donation reporting and the same bans on foreign donations and foreign campaigners that apply during federal elections.

Our Government will continue to work towards an electoral system that ensures fairness, equity of access and transparency. Thank you for bringing the matters referred to in the petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Special Minister of State, Senator Farrell
Electoral Roll
Dear Ms Templeman

On 14 January 2022, your predecessor, Mr Ken O'Dowd, referred petition EN3735 about voting rights of New Zealand citizens and permanent residents to the former Special Minister of State, the Hon. Ben Morton. As this was not responded to during the term of the former Government, I am responding as the current Special Minister of State.

The Labor Party has led legislation for significant federal electoral reform in Australia. Reforms by the Hawke Government in the 1980s provided the framework for Australia's contemporary elections and our democracy. Importantly, that Government transformed our democratic institutions with the creation of the independent Australian Electoral Commission to conduct and oversee elections. It also increased transparency in our democratic system by introducing a regime for the regulation and disclosure of political donations and electoral expenditure.

Labor continued to deliver electoral reform through the direct enrolment update program, introduced by the Gillard Government. More recently, from opposition we successfully linked public election funding to campaign expenditure, preventing parties from profiting from the electoral system, and forced the Liberal/National Government to ban foreign political donations, protecting our democracy from foreign interference. Already in this term, I have approved regulatory change to expand the forms of identification a voter can use to enrol or update their enrolment to include Medicare numbers and Australian citizenship notice numbers.

The Albanese Government continues to work to further reform our electoral system and democratic institutions. As part of our commitment to implement the Uluru Statement from the Heart, a referendum will be held between October and December 2023 to recognise Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples in the Constitution by establishing an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice.

This petition requests a review into voting rights, particularly for New Zealand citizens and permanent residents who have resided in Australia for five years or more. Last year, the Prime Minister, the Hon. Anthony Albanese MP, considered the issue of voting rights for New Zealanders in Australia. At the time the Prime Minister confirmed that as part of the usual parliamentary committee review after a federal election in Australia, our Government would ask the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters to consider the voting rights of New Zealand people who are here in Australia contributing to our society.

Following this, when I wrote to the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters to initiate inquiry into the 2022 federal election, I asked the Committee to inquire into increasing electoral participation and enfranchisement generally, and specifically in relation to New Zealand citizens residing in Australia and Australian permanent residents and new Australian citizens.

Historically, legislative changes to Australia's electoral system have occurred based on bi-partisan inquiries by this parliamentary committee. I now await the Committee's report, which will provide its investigations into this issue and, I expect, the members' recommendation on whether this is, or is not, an appropriate reform. I encourage the petitioner and interested parties to follow the work of the Committee and submissions made to it, which can be found here: www.aph.gov.au/Parliamentary_Business/Committees/Joint/Electoral_Matters.

It is also relevant to note progress our Labor Government has made in addressing citizenship processing times. The Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, the Hon. Andrew Giles MP, recently announced that in our first year, the Albanese Government has reduced citizenship processing times by 42 per cent to an average of seven months. This progress will support those New Zealanders who successfully apply for Australian citizenship to seek access to enfranchisement in Australia sooner.
Thank you for bringing the matters referred to in the petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Special Minister of State, Senator Farrell
COVID-19: Vaccine
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence regarding Petition EN4108 requesting that the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) review its decision to not recognise the Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine for people aged over 60 years. I apologise for the delay in responding.

The TGA, part of the Department of Health and Aged Care, played an important role in conducting assessments of information regarding COVID-19 vaccines that were being used globally for the purpose of international travel. The information from the TGA's assessments was used to inform decisions at Australia's international border with respect to incoming travellers.

Based on an initial assessment of data, the TGA recognised the Sinopharm vaccine for the purpose of inbound travel to Australia for people under 60 years of age in November 2021 due to the lower absolute risk of severe infection/hospitalisation in younger people. The TGA continued to monitor the scientific literature, including the results of real-world evidence and ongoing trials assessing the effectiveness of the Sinopharm vaccine, and amended its initial decision and removed the age limit on 10 May 2022. This decision meant that the Sinopharm vaccine was recognised for all ages for the purpose of inbound travel to Australia.
Further to this, since 6 July 2022 people are now able to travel to and from Australia without being required to declare their COVID-19 vaccine status.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Private Health Insurance
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 7 November 2022 to the Minister for Health and Aged Care, the Hon Mark Butler MP, regarding petition number EN4118, relating to application of the Medicare Levy Surcharge (MLS) on households. I am responding as the Acting Minister for Health and Aged Care.

The MLS was introduced in 1997 to encourage higher income earners and higher income households, with a greater capacity to pay, to purchase Australian private hospital insurance and where possible, use the private hospital system to reduce demand on the public system, Medicare.

In this regard, the MLS makes an important contribution to supporting access to public health care for those Australians whose personal circumstances are such that they may not be able to afford to purchase private health insurance.
I also note income thresholds protect lower earning households from paying the MLS, even in the instance no family member has purchased private hospital insurance.

Indexation of the income tiers which determine application of the MLS recommenced on 1 July 2023, after having been held at 2014-15 levels. This means fewer people are now subject to the MLS. Further information about these changes is available at www.ato.gov.au by searching for 'Medicare Levy Surcharge'.

The Australian Government recognises the importance of improving the sustainability, affordability and value of private health insurance, including in the context of the benefits it offers individuals and their families, as well as the Australian health care system.

In this context, studies into the key private health insurance regulatory settings, including the MLS, were recently completed. The final reports for the studies can be found on the Department of Health and Aged Care's website at www.consultations.health.gov.au by searching for 'private health'.

The department is engaging with stakeholders on the studies and is accepting feedback until 15 August 2023. The Government will consider stakeholder feedback with a view to inform potential changes to MLS arrangements.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Acting Minister for Health and Aged Care, Ms Wells
COVID-19: International Travel
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 21 June 2023 to the Minister for Health and Aged Care, the Hon Mark Butler MP, regarding a petition to remove all remaining travel restrictions when the Biosecurity (Human Biosecurity Emergency) (Human Coronavirus with Pandemic Potential) Declaration 2020 lapsed on 17 April 2022 (Petition Number: EN4135). I am responding as the Acting Minister for Health and Aged Care.
I confirm that the human biosecurity emergency period which was declared under section 475 of the Biosecurity Act 2015, on 18 March 2020, ended on 17 April 2022.
Currently, the Australian Government does not have any COVID-19 requirements or restrictions in place for travellers entering or departing Australia.
The Government will continue to be guided by the latest available medical advice, monitor global developments, and adjust its international border controls, where required.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Acting Minister for Health and Aged Care, Ms Wells
Health Care
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence regarding Petition EN4139, requesting an amendment to the Distribution Priority Area (DPA) classification for The Redlands, Queensland. I apologise for the delay in responding.

The Australian Government is strongly committed to improving access to health services for all Australians. The Government recognises the unique challenges currently facing the health system and is focused on improving the capacity, quality, and distribution of health services to meet the needs of all communities.

The Government's ongoing commitment to improving healthcare was reflected in the 2023-24 Budget released on 9 May 2023. The Budget provides an historic $6.1 billion investment in Medicare, to lay the foundations for significant reforms. This Budget responds to the recommendations of the Strengthening Medicare Taskforce and takes the key steps needed to address the many pressing challenges in our healthcare system, including the fact that seeing a GP has become harder and more expensive, especially in regional, rural, and remote areas. A Budget overview is available at: www.health.gov.au/sites/default/files/2023-05/overview-budget-2023-24_0.pdf.

This includes, $17.5 million committed under the Strengthening Medicare Package—the Supporting Healthcare and Support Services in Thin Markets measure to improve access to health services in environments where the market for health services is thin or failing. As part of this measure, the Government has committed to undertake a stocktake and review of distribution program and policy levers, including the DPA mechanism, to support the development of innovative delivery models to support service access in thin markets and to improve the equitable access to health services in the longer term.

The DPA mechanism is used to identify areas of GP shortage throughout Australia, allowing the Government to direct location-restricted doctors into areas of greatest need. DPA status does not guarantee recruitment of a doctor but allows practices to access an expanded pool of doctors from which they may recruit, including Overseas Trained Doctors and Australian-trained Bonded doctors.

The Redlands encompasses a large geographic area across two GP catchments under the DPA mechanism: Cleveland-Stradbroke and Capalaba. In the most recent DPA annual update on 21 July 2022, both Cleveland-Stradbroke and Capalaba catchments were assessed as being more than 10% above the benchmark for distribution, indicating that these areas benefit from greater GP service access than other comparable areas of Australia.

However, the DPA system also takes into consideration an area's geographic remoteness under the Modified Monash Model (MMM) classification system, with all areas classified MM 2-7 under the MMM automatically deemed DPA. This means that some areas of the Cleveland-Stradbroke catchment, classified MM2-6 under the MMM, attract DPA status. The remaining MMl areas of Cleveland-Stradbroke and all of Capalaba are classified non-DPA.

The Government recognises that occasionally there are circumstances within a GP catchment which are not fully captured in the annual updates. For this reason, there is an exceptional circumstances review process that allows eligible practices to request a review of their catchment's designation as non-DPA.

If eligible practices within The Redlands believe there are exceptional circumstances which have not been considered in the annual update, they may apply for a review of their catchment's DPA status. To do this, practices will need to contact their local Rural Workforce Agency (RWA) to submit an application. The RWA for Queensland is Health Workforce Queensland. Health Workforce Queensland can best be contacted on (07) 3105 7800 or via their website at www.healthworkforce.com.au.

For more information on the DPA exceptional circumstances review, please refer to the Department of Health and Aged Care's website at www.health.gov.au/health-topics/rural- health-workforce/classifications/dpa/request-review.

Please note that a change in DPA classification will only allow practices to recruit from a slightly wider GP pool, as doctors would need to be a Fellow (due to MM1 classification) or an international medical graduate with temporary residency status.

Practices can also access additional support to attract and retain GPs into their area from their local Primary Health Network (PHN), the Brisbane South PHN or, if within an MM2-7 area, their RWA, Health Workforce Queensland.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
COVID-19: Vaccine
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence regarding Petition EN4149 asking the House to make sure that the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) prioritises the provisional approval of Vaxine's COVID-19 vaccine and waives any application fee. I apologise for the delay in responding.

The Australian Government is committed to providing access to free and effective COVID-19 vaccines to everyone living in Australia who is eligible. To do so, the Government has invested in a diverse portfolio of COVID-19 vaccines that use a variety of technical platforms, securing supply for all eligible populations within Australia.

I refute the assertion that Vaxine Pty Ltd did not receive Government-funded grants. As noted in our response to petition EN3620 on 15 August 2022, Vaxine Pty Ltd, the company developing Flinders University's COVID-19 vaccine candidate "COVAX-19(R)", was funded $1 million through the Government's Biomedical Translation Bridge Program, an initiative of the Medical Research Future Fund.

On 15 December 2021 the TGA granted a provisional determination to Vaxine Pty Ltd for its COVID-19 vaccine, Recombinant SARS-CoV-2 rS (Vax-S-dTM-W1) (SPIKOGEN VACCINE), which is also known as COVAX-19. In May 2022, the provisional determination for this vaccine candidate was extended. This lapsed on 14 December 2022.

By granting a provisional determination, the TGA made a decision that Vaxine Pty Ltd was eligible to apply for provisional registration for its vaccine on the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods (ARTG). Provisional determination is the first step in the provisional registration process. Importantly, this does not mean that the sponsor will submit an application or that the TGA will approve the subsequent application. Registration and supply in Australia will only commence should the vaccine be approved as safe and effective by the TGA.
Despite receiving provisional determination, the TGA has not received an application from Vaxine Pty Ltd to provisionally register its COVID-19 vaccine candidate.

I must emphasise that, if the sponsor holds the appropriate evidence, they are welcome to make an application to the TGA to register their vaccine on the ARTG at any time. If an application for a COVID-19 vaccine is received, it will be treated with the greatest priority. However, the Government cannot compel a sponsor to submit an application for registration. Furthermore, in the absence of a formal application, the TGA does not have the legal ability to initiate an evaluation of the product.

Also, as outlined in the response to EN3620, the results of clinical trials conducted overseas, such as those from the Phase Ill clinical trial undertaken by Vaxine Pty Ltd in collaboration with Iranian biotechnology company CinnaGen, can be used to support the sponsor's future application to the TGA.

Finally, it is not possible for the TGA to waive the application fee to provisionally register Vaxine's COVID-19 vaccine. Similar to other international regulators, the TGA is required to recover its costs for all activities that fall under the scope of the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989. This includes evaluating applications for new vaccines. I can also confirm that sponsors of the COVID-19 vaccines that have been provisionally approved have paid all of the relevant fees.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Food Labelling
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 7 November 2022 to the Minister for Health and Aged Care, the Hon Mark Butler MP, regarding a petition for food serving size on the nutritional label using common measuring units (Petition Number: EN4163). I am responding as the Acting Minister for Health and Aged Care.

The request asks the House of Representatives to make it mandatory for food companies to state the amount of food a serving size is on the nutritional label using common measurements appropriate to the food.

The Australian Government recognises that a nutritious diet is one of the most influential factors contributing to the overall health and wellbeing of all Australians. To assist consumers to make informed food purchases, the Government requires certain mandatory information to be listed on food labels. This includes the serving size information on the Nutrition Information Panel (NIP).

In Australia, Food Standards Australia New Zealand (FSANZ) is responsible for the development and regulation of the Australia New Zealand Food Standards Code (Code), and the standards of the Code are enforced by the states and territories. The Code outlines the requirements that are relevant to all foods, including specific labelling and information requirements that apply to certain food products.

Standard 1.2.8 of the Code sets out the requirements on what must be included on the NIP. This includes what constitutes as a serving of a particular food, the number of servings in the package and the quantity of food in a serving. This information is listed at the top of the NIP and often includes common measurements appropriate to the particular food, for example 'Serving size: 30g (2/3 metric cup)', or 'Serving size: 23.8g (4 biscuits)'. It is important to note that for products that do not have common consumption measurements, use of serving size information in grams or millilitres is more appropriate.

Another important consideration is that serving sizes listed on NIPs are determined by food manufacturers and vary between different foods. A serving size may therefore not be indicative of what an appropriate portion size is for that particular food for different population groups.

The Government supports the Australian Dietary Guidelines (Guidelines) to help consumers make more informed decisions by providing information on the amount and types of foods people require to promote health and wellbeing and reduce the risk of diet-related conditions including obesity and chronic health conditions such as type 2 diabetes and cardiovascular disease.

The Guidelines provide the recommended number of daily serves an individual requires from each of the five food groups. The serve size is a set amount (as outlined in the Guidelines) that does not change, which differs from manufacturer determined serving sizes. The number of serves of each of the five food groups an individual needs to consume each day varies between individually due to factors including gender, weight, height, physical activity level and health conditions. The Australian Guide to Healthy Eating provides helpful visual representations of the proportion of the five food groups recommended for consumption each day.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Acting Minister for Health and Aged Care, Ms Wells
COVID-19: Vaccine
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence regarding petition EN4169 and access to Evusheld (R) (tixagevimab and cilgavimab) for immunocompromised individuals. I apologise for the delay in responding.

The Australian Government has invested in a diverse range of COVID-19 treatment options to ensure Australia will have sufficient treatment supply to manage different stages of disease. Evusheld was the first non-vaccine medication secured by the Government for the prevention of COVID-19 in people who are at risk of infection but have not been exposed to the virus. Evusheld is not recommended as a substitute for COVID-19 vaccination.

In early January 2023, the Government secured up to an additional 12,000 (300-300mg) doses of Evusheld from AstraZeneca for the National Medical Stockpile (NMS) to continue to support patients with severe immunocompromise. This was in addition to the 36,000 (150-l50mg) doses secured in late 2020 and early 2021. All supplies of Evusheld have been provided to state and territory health departments to distribute within their jurisdiction. Each state and territory is responsible for managing the distribution of Evusheld in accordance with its COVID-19 care arrangements.

Evusheld was first provisionally approved by the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) on 24 February 2022 for the prevention (pre-exposure prophylaxis) of COVID-19 in people with sub-optimal or no protection from COVID-19 vaccines. On 12 December 2022, the TGA amended the conditions of its provisional approval for the use of Evusheld for pre-exposure prophylaxis in individuals 12 years and over, increasing the required dosage regime from 150-l50mg to 300-300mg dose with the option to provide repeat dosing every six months. Evusheld also received provisional approval as a treatment for adults with COVID-19, who do not require supplemental oxygen and who are at increased risk of progressing to severe COVID-19.

On 2 March 2023, the TGA reported emerging data showed monoclonal antibodies, such as Evusheld, demonstrated a significant decrease in their in-vitro neutralising activities against many newer circulating variants, particularly Omicron subvariants, but noted the regulatory status remained unchanged.
The TGA's full statement is available at www.tga.gov.au/news/news/update-effectiveness-monoclonal-antibodies-against-covid-variants.

You may also be interested to know that at its 7 December 2022 meeting, the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC), considered a PBS listing of Evusheld (tixagevimab 150mg with cilgavimab 150mg), for the second time, for pre-exposure prophylaxis against COVID-19 infection in certain individuals. The PBAC again did not recommend the listing of Evusheld on the PBS. Full details of the PBACs outcome is available at www.pbs.gov.au/info/industry/listing/elements/pbac-meetings/pbac-outcomes/recommendations-made-by-the-pbac-december-2022-intracycle.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Rural and Regional Health Services
Dear Chair

I refer to your correspondence regarding petition EN4211 requesting the Australian Government contribute funding to build a new single site hospital to service the Albury Wodonga, northeast Victoria and southern New South Wales regions. I apologise for the delay in responding.

The Government recognises the important contribution the unique cross border arrangements make to servicing the health needs of the Albury Wodonga and surrounding regions. The Government remains committed to working with state and territory governments to improve access to health and hospital services so that all Australians receive appropriate health care when and where they need it, including in regional, rural, and remote areas.

The National Health Reform Agreement (NHRA) sets out the financial and governance arrangements for the funding of public hospital services in Australia. Under the NHRA, the state and territory governments have committed to providing eligible patients with the choice to receive public hospital services free-of-charge, on the basis of clinical need and within a clinically appropriate period. Through the NHRA, the Government makes a significant funding contribution to assist states and territories with the costs of delivering public hospital services.

The two local hospital networks responsible for delivering public hospital services in the Albury Wodonga region, the Albury New South Wales Local Health District and Albury Wodonga Health, received a combined $105.3 million in Australian Government Activity Based Funding for public hospitals services in 2021-22. Additionally, in 2021-22, the Government made a block funded contribution of a combined $18.9 million to these two local hospital networks for services such as teaching, training, and research, and those provided by small rural hospitals.

The NHRA recognises that states and territories are the system managers of their public hospital systems, responsible for the day-to-day administration of their public hospitals, and for planning and funding the infrastructure necessary to support the delivery of their public hospital services. As such, decisions regarding the establishment of a new single site Albury Wodonga Hospital are a matter for the New South Wales and Victorian Governments.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Cystic Fibrosis
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence regarding petition number EN4275 requesting extending access to cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) modulators such as Trikafta(R) (elexacaftor/tezacaftor/ivacaftor with ivacaftor) on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) for the treatment of cystic fibrosis associated with a broader range of mutations.

The Australian Government currently subsidises four CFTR modulators through the PBS: Trikafta(R), Symdeko(R) (tezacaftor/ivacaftor with ivacaftor), Orkambi(R) (lumacaftor/ivacaftor) and Kalydeco(R) (ivacaftor).

Trikafta(R) was recently extended on the PBS from 1 May 2023, providing subsidised access for children with cystic fibrosis aged 6 to 11 years, who have at least one F508del mutation in the CFTR gene.

The Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC), an independent expert advisory body comprising doctors, other health professionals and consumer representatives, makes recommendations to the Government about PBS listings. Under legislation, the Government cannot list a new medicine on the PBS unless the PBAC makes a recommendation in favour of its listing.

The pharmaceutical company responsible for Trikafta(R), Symdeko(R), Orkambi(R) and Kalydeco(R), Vertex Pharmaceuticals (Australia) Pty Ltd, has not made an application to the PBAC to extend the listing of these medicines to include a broader range of mutations.

Further, the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA), Australia's regulator of medicines and other therapeutic goods, has not approved Trikafta(R) for broader clinical used in Australia. Medicines typically are not listed on the PBS for clinical uses that have not been approved by the TGA.

Consideration of a medicine for TGA registration and PBS listing is generally initiated by the sponsor making applications to the TGA and PBAC, respectively. Pharmaceutical companies have access to the scientific data and other information necessary to inform the PBAC's consideration.
The PBAC would welcome further applications related to the use of Trikafta(R) or other CFTR modulators at any time.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
People with Disability
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence regarding petition EN4290 concerning financial assistance for Australians with epilepsy. I apologise for the delay in responding.

The Australian Government is committed to reducing the impact that chronic conditions, such as epilepsy, place on Australians, including families and carers. The Government recognises that effective services and care can improve health and social outcomes for people suffering from epilepsy.

The National Disability Insurance Scheme (NDIS) needs to determine whether a support for a participant is most appropriately funded or provided by the NDIS according to section 34(1)(f) of the National Disability Insurance Scheme Act 2013 (NDIS Act). The NDIS provides supports to help a person to be more independent and pursue their goals. The supports must directly relate to the functional impacts of a person's disability.

A person may satisfy the NDIS access requirements regardless of whether their impairment came about through birth, disease, injury or accident. All people with disability are able to access the NDIS if they meet the age, residency and disability or early intervention requirements as set out in the NDIS Act. To be eligible for NDIS funding, the disease or medical condition must cause permanent impairment (physical, intellectual, cognitive, neurological, visual, hearing or psychosocial), resulting in significant disability.

The NDIA's Partners in The Community Program can connect people with mainstream and community supports, as well as provide information about supports provided by state and territory governments. Mainstream supports are accessible from other government funded services, such as health, mental health and education. Community supports are available through community organisations, such as religious groups and supports from local councils.

The Government is providing $20 million over five years (2019-20 to 2023-24) to the Epilepsy Foundation to deliver the Epilepsy Smart Australia Program Pilot, a national program for epilepsy support and management. Activities include the delivery of the National Epilepsy Support Service, to provide one-on-one individualised support to people with epilepsy, their families and carers, and to deliver education and training to specific sectors to meet the needs of people living with epilepsy.

The Government is also providing a further $1.02 million over three years (2021-22 to 2023-24) to Epilepsy Action Australia for the Epilepsy Action Response Service, which supports the establishment and operation of a dedicated national telehealth service to people affected by epilepsy to provide expert clinical information, offer support and guidance, advice on self-management and referrals.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Gender Dysphoria
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence regarding Petition EN4296 requesting that top and bottom surgery should be covered by Medicare. I apologise for the delay in responding.

The Australian Government is working to achieve improved access to care, support and better physical, mental health and wellbeing outcomes for LGBTIQA+ people, including transgender and gender diverse people. The Government recognises that transgender and gender diverse individuals have unique and often complex health needs and are at an increased risk of poorer physical and mental health outcomes compared to the general population.

The Government is committed to supporting Australians to access high quality health care by providing Medicare benefits (rebates) for services listed on the Medicare Benefits Schedule (MBS), subsidised pharmaceuticals available through the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, and free hospital services for public patients in public hospitals.

While there are no specific MBS items for gender affirmation surgery, Medicare rebates are available for patients to cover a range of surgical procedures and specialist consultations that may be performed as part of the gender affirmation process, if the services are deemed by the treating practitioner to be clinically relevant to the care of their patient.

The Department of Health and Aged Care is consulting with the Australian Society of Plastic Surgeons and relevant clinical colleges on improving access to Medicare rebates for people who receive gender affirmation treatment as a private patient. This includes consideration of listing various procedures performed in gender affirmation process on the MBS following advice from the Medical Services Advisory Committee.

While the Government is responsible for setting Medicare benefits, doctors are able to set their own fees and the actual fee charged is a matter between the doctor and the patient. Medical practitioners are encouraged to consider their patients' personal circumstances when determining the fees they charge, and many do.

On 1 March 2023, the Government announced a pathway to better health and wellbeing for LGBTIQA+ communities. This includes the development of Australia's first 10 Year National Action Plan for the Health and Wellbeing of LGBTIQA+ people (Action Plan) and a $26 million investment in health and medical research focusing on LGBTIQA+ communities under the Medical Research Future Fund.
The Action Plan will be informed by national consultation with LGBTIQA+ people, an Expert Advisory Group, and the lived experience of LGBTIQA+ people and their families, and community organisations.

The Government recognises that trans and gender diverse Australians are proportionately affected by mental illness and often face additional barriers in seeking the help and treatment they need. The following services are available to support the mental health and wellbeing of transgender and other gender diverse people and their families:

headspace (www.headspace.org.au/online-and-phone-support) or on 1800 650 890 provides access to a safe online community, headspace where young transgender and gender diverse people can connect with their peers and seek support in peer-led communities and group chats.
Qlife (www.qlife.org.au) provides Australia-wide anonymous LGBTIQA+ peer support and referral by telephone (1300 184 527) and webchat every day from 3pm-midnight.

Head to Health (www.headtohealth.gov.au) is the Australian Government's digital mental health gateway that aims to help people more easily access information, advice and free or low-cost telephone and online mental health services and supports that most suit their needs.
Lifeline on 13 1114 or via its chat service (www.lifeline.org.au).
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Health Care
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 7 November 2022 regarding petition EN4298 which requests the Australian Government increase funding to the health and hospital system.

The Government is committed to improving access to health and hospital services so that all Australians receive appropriate health care when and where they need it, including in regional, rural and remote areas.

Under the National Health Reform Agreement (NHRA), all state and territory governments have committed to providing eligible patients with the choice to receive public hospital services free-of-charge, on the basis of clinical need, within a clinically appropriate period.

Through the NHRA, the Government provides a significant funding contribution to assist states and territories with the costs of delivering public hospital services. Under the NHRA, the majority of public hospitals are funded on an activity basis. Activity Based Funding provides funding to public hospitals based on the number and mix of patients they treat. If a hospital treats more patients, it receives more funding. This supports the Government's commitment to ensuring access to health care, when and where people need it.

The Government's funding contribution for public hospital services in Australia under the NHRA has grown from $13.3 billion in 2012-13 to $24.1 billion in 2021-22, an increase of 81%. Between 2022-23 and 2026-27, the Government's funding contribution for public hospital services in Australia under the NHRA is estimated to grow from $25.6 billion in 2022-23 to $34.3 billion in 2026-27, an increase of 34%.

The NHRA recognises that state and territory governments are the system managers of their public hospital systems, responsible for the day-to-day administration and performance of their public hospitals. This includes decisions on funding over and above the Government contribution under the NHRA, as well as management of staff resources.

The Mid-term Review (Review) of the NHRA is currently underway. The Review, which is independently led, is examining whether the NHRA is meeting its stated objectives. The Review is considering whether the NHRA's health planning, funding and governance arrangements are still fit-for-purpose, particularly given emerging priorities for better integrated care and more seamless interfaces between health and primary care, aged care and disability systems.
It will also examine other matters including the impact of external factors such as COVID-19 on the demand for hospital services.

The Review is due to be completed by the end of 2023 and will provide advice to all Health Ministers on potential options for future reform and agreements. Health Ministers will then work together to consider the outcomes and recommendations of the Review.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Endometriosis
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence regarding petition EN4330 asking that Endometriosis be recognised as a disability.

The Australian Government has made the health and wellbeing of all women and girls a priority. This includes a commitment to implementing a suite of endometriosis support measures announced in the 2022-23 Budget.

A key component of these measures is the establishment of specialised GP clinics across Australia to provide access to specialised endometriosis and chronic pelvic pain diagnosis, treatment and management, with a focus on improving diagnostic timeliness and to promote early access to intervention, care and treatment options. Information on these specialised endometriosis and chronic pelvic pain clinics can be found on the Department of Health and Aged Care's website www.health.gov.au/our-work/endometriosis-and-pelvic- pain-clinics.
Other measures to help women to find more appropriate care and better manage the impact of endometriosis and pelvic pain include:
access to a new Medicare funded magnetic resonance imaging scan to assist in the investigation of infertility for those with severe endometriosis and other conditions

a review of the Medicare Benefits Schedule and Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme items used to support the diagnosis and treatment of endometriosis. The review will report on available treatments for endometriosis and recommendations for both improved utilisation of items and promotion of available treatments
development of an Endometriosis Management Plan to support patients in primary care
support to the National Endometriosis Clinical and Scientific Trials Network to continue growing research capacity and address research gaps
funding for an Endometriosis Living Guideline to support new and ongoing research into the diagnosis and management of endometriosis
promotion of the Australian Clinical Practice Guideline for the Diagnosis and Management of Endometriosis

funding for increasing awareness of endometriosis amongst priority populations, implementing a Mentor Program to support those newly diagnosed with endometriosis and implementing a Workplace Assistance Program to support employees and employers to navigate discussions in the workplace
continued support for the EndoZone digital platform to provide consumer access to evidence-based information.

The department's webpages have been updated and include the Endometriosis Progress Report (Report) against the measures from the October 2022 Budget. The Report can be found on the department's website by searching 'what we're doing about endometriosis'.

Regarding recognising endometriosis for the purposes of disability support, any person with a disability can access the National Disability Insurance Scheme (NDIS) if they meet the requirements set out in the National Disability Insurance Scheme Act 2013 (NDIS Act), including age, residency and disability or early intervention requirements. Generally, a person will be eligible for the NDIS if their disability is, or is likely to be, permanent and causes a substantial reduction in their capacity for communication, social interaction, learning, mobility, self-care or self-management.

The NDIS does not determine eligibility based solely on types of disability or on the presence of an underlying condition, illness or injury. People with endometriosis can become NDIS participants if they meet the requirements set out in the NDIS Act, including providing evidence of the functional impact of their disability on activities of daily living. However, not all people with endometriosis will meet the access requirements under the NDIS Act. In all cases, any person with disability should test their eligibility for the NDIS with the National Disability Insurance Agency (NDIA) and, should they be determined as eligible, the NDIA will provide the person with an individualised package of support that matches their circumstances and goals. A participant's NDIS plan may also include some kinds of health supports where those supports are required because of their disability and form a regular part of the participant's daily life.

Access lists were introduced during the transition phase of the Scheme to expedite consideration of access for some cohorts. They do not override the provisions of the NDIS Act and people whose disabilities are not listed, such as people with endometriosis, can still become NDIS participants if they meet the requirements in the Act. Meeting the requirements of the NDIS Act, not having a condition on a list, is what determines eligibility. A participant's NDIS plan may also include some health supports where those supports are required because of the disability and when they form a regular part of the participant's daily life. Further information can be found at www.ndis.gov.au.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Type 2 Diabetes
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 7 November 2022 regarding Petition EN4341—a proposal to extend access to subsidised continuous glucose monitoring (CGM) products through the National Diabetes Services Scheme (NDSS) to people with type 2 diabetes. I am responding as the Acting Minister for Health and Aged Care.
The Australian Government is committed to supporting Australians with diabetes and their families.

The Government provides considerable financial support to people with diabetes through the subsidy of essential medicines, like insulin, under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) and other diabetes-related products, like blood glucose test strips, through the NDSS.
In 2021-22, PBS expenditure on medicines for diabetes was $804 million and expenditure on products for diabetes supplied through the NDSS was over $196 million.
Since 1 July 2022, all Australians with type 1 diabetes have been able to access subsidised CGM products through the NDSS.

This follows implementation of a $273.1 million election commitment made by the Government to provide an additional 71,000 people with type 1 diabetes access to subsidised CGM products, with an affordable co-payment equivalent to $32.50 per month.

Access arrangements will not change for people already eligible to receive free CGM products under the NDSS (including children and young people aged under 21 with type 1 diabetes, women with type 1 diabetes who are planning for pregnancy, pregnant or immediately post-pregnancy, and people with type 1 diabetes aged 21 and over who have a concession card).

Following implementation of this expansion, the Government will continue to monitor the operation of the scheme. This will inform government consideration of any further expansion of the scheme to adults with other forms of diabetes.
Further information about the NDSS and CGM products, including detailed eligibility criteria, is available at www.ndss.com.au.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Acting Minister for Health and Aged Care, Ms Wells
National Security
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN4379—Reduce the timeframe of all 99 years leases to 18 years. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

Petition EN4379 raises national interest and national security concerns regarding the duration of leases held by foreign investors over Australian property and utilities. While the Commonwealth is responsible for regulating foreign investment, lease arrangements are the responsibility of state and territory governments and regulated by their respective laws and regulations.

However, the Australian Government recognises community concerns about foreign ownership of certain Australian assets. That is why the foreign investment review framework allows the Government to take these concerns into consideration, by reviewing foreign investment proposals on a case-by-case basis to ensure they are not contrary to the national interest or national security.

Under the framework, proposed foreign investments may be screened under a 'national interest test' or a narrower 'national security test'. In assessing a proposal's impact on the national interest, the Government considers: national security; character of the investor; competition; impact on the economy and community; and other Government policies (including tax).

Investments that pose national security concerns—that is, investments in an industry sector critical to Australia's national security—trigger mandatory notification obligations under the foreign investment framework. For example, this might include acquisitions involving or connected with critical infrastructure and services or technologies essential to Australia's defence or intelligence capability.

The definition of a 'national security business' under the foreign investment framework includes entities regulated under the Security of Critical Infrastructure Act 2018 (the SOCI Act). The SOCI Act is the regulatory framework for managing risks relating to Australia's critical infrastructure.

In assessing these investments, Treasury alongside relevant national security agencies, engages with industry and relevant stakeholders to undertake strategic analysis on sectoral issues relating to foreign investment. This strategic analysis is used to identify emerging national security risks across industries and sectors and makes whole-of-government recommendations.

If it is ultimately determined that a proposal would be contrary to the national interest or to national security, it will not be approved, or conditions will be imposed to mitigate risks to our national interest.

Foreign investment plays an important and beneficial role in the Australian economy. It helps drive economic growth, creates skilled jobs, improves access to overseas markets and enhances productivity. Foreign investment has helped build Australia's economy, and it will continue to enhance the wellbeing of Australians by supporting economic growth and innovation into the future.

Should the petitioner require further information on Australia's foreign investment policy and framework, I have attached Australia's Foreign Investment Policy and Guidance Note 8: National Security. Further details, including Guidance Notes on other aspects of the framework, can be found at www.firb.gov.au.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Treasurer, Dr Chalmers
Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence regarding petition number EN4383 (with 6,687 signatures), about medicinal cannabis cost issues.

I am aware many Australians are experiencing difficulties with the cost of medicinal cannabis, and patients are reporting benefits since commencing the medicine, including being able to transition from opioids or 'alternative sources' of cannabis.

Medicinal cannabis products are regulated as medicines in Australia. The Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA), as Australia's regulator of medicines, currently provides safe and legal access to medicinal cannabis in appropriate circumstances, Generally, medicines used in Australia must be included in the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods (ARTG), which is administered by the TGA. Sativex(R) (nabiximols) and Epidyolex (cannabidiol) are the only approved medicinal cannabis products included in the ARTG, approved under the standard and priority pathways, respectively.

Sativex(R) was approved by TGA in 2012 (ARTG 181978) for moderate to severe multiple sclerosis, but is not currently listed on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS). Epidyolex(R) was approved by TGA in 2020 (ARTG 328860) for seizures associated with Lennox-Gastaut syndrome or Dravet syndrome. In May 2021, Epidyolex(R) was listed on the PBS for Dravet syndrome (severe epilepsy in infancy). In June 2023 it was also PBS listed for Lennox-Gastaut syndrome (another severe form of epilepsy that begins in early childhood). For a medicine to be listed on the PBS, it usually has to be registered by the TGA. The TGA would consider any future applications for medicinal cannabis products, where data was provided on quality, safety and efficacy. The Australian Government is unable to compel a pharmaceutical company to submit applications for ARTG registration of a medicine, and the TGA cannot evaluate a medicine without an application.

The PBS is the main mechanism through which the Government subsidises the cost of medicines for Australian patients. Under legislation, the Government can only list a medicine on the PBS when the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC) recommends a listing. The PBAC is an independent and expert body, comprising doctors, health professionals, health economists and consumer representatives. Its primary role is to advise me, as Minister for Health and Aged Care, about medicines that should be PBS-subsidised.

When the PBAC evaluates applications for PBS subsidy, it is legally required to consider effectiveness and cost of the medicine, compared to alternative treatments. There is no legal provision for subsidised supply of a non-PBS-listed medicine, or for a PBS-listed medicine outside the terms of its listing (or specific restrictions). No exceptions are permitted for individual patients, even in particular cases where the medicine might be beneficial or recommended on clinical grounds.

Currently, most medicinal cannabis products are 'unapproved', but the TGA can approve any medical practitioner to prescribe an unapproved medicinal cannabis product for an individual patient, through the Special Access B Scheme. In addition, under the Authorised Prescriber Scheme, a suitably authorised doctor can prescribe products without obtaining patient-by-patient approvals from TGA. A number of companies are conducting clinical trials with the intent of lodging applications with TGA in the coming year. The TGA welcomes and encourages discussions with prospective companies about the regulatory process for medicinal cannabis products. Similarly, the PBAC's consideration (for subsequent PBS listing) is generally initiated when the pharmaceutical company applies for PBS listing, as companies usually hold scientific data and other information necessary to inform the PBAC's consideration. A pharmaceutical company is a private entity that makes its own decisions about availability of its medicines, pricing of its medicines in the private market and whether it will apply for PBS subsidy. The Government cannot compel companies to submit applications for PBS listing.

Patients and treating doctors can contact companies responsible for 'approved' and 'unapproved' medicinal cannabis products, to ask if they are considering submitting applications for particular medical conditions. The Office of Drug Control publishes a comprehensive list (and contact details) of Australian medicinal cannabis manufacturers and suppliers, licensed under the Narcotic Drugs Act 1967, available at www.odc.gov.au/manufacturers-and-suppliers-medicinal-cannabis-products. While speaking with any company, patients or their treating doctors can ask if access to the medicine is available at reduced cost, through a compassionate or expanded access program. Decisions about these programs are a matter for each company.

Treating doctors can consider applying (on a patient's behalf) to the drug and therapeutics committee of the local public hospital to seek assistance with cost. Some states and territories are subsidising the cost for some patients through access programs or clinical trials. Private health insurers are free to pay benefits under general treatment cover for the full price of a medicine, noting this is a commercial decision for each health insurer. Medicines not PBS-listed are dispensed as private prescriptions, and patient charges for private prescriptions are a matter for each pharmacy. Price competition applies to products not available on the PBS and patients can speak to their pharmacist about prices, including if they find a cheaper price elsewhere.
All aspects of patient care, including recommendations about appropriate treatments (or access to relevant clinical trials), are the responsibility of a patient's treating doctor.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Dental Health
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 7 November 2022 regarding Petition EN4385 seeking lower fees for general dental services and dental procedures.

The private sector in Australia primarily employs 85% of dental practitioners, and accounts for around 80% of dental visits. I understand the petitioners' concern relates to the fees private dental practitioners may charge for services. The Australian Government does not have authority to determine the fees charged by private dental practitioners in their private practice. Dental practitioners operating as private businesses are free to place their own value on the services they provide.

State and territory governments have primary responsibility for public dental services including funding, management of waiting lists and determining what services they provide. The Government is aware of the barriers to accessing affordable dental services and supports a range of targeted programs for children and adult concession card holders to access care.
The Government supports state and territory governments to increase access to public dental care by:
providing additional funding for adult public dental services
making a significant funding contribution through the National Health Reform Agreement (NHRA) for public hospital services, including admitted and non-admitted dental services.

In the 2023-24 Budget, the Government announced funding for states and territories of $215.6 million over two years in the Federation Funding Agreement. This will provide services to an additional 360,000 public dental patients while the Government and states and territories negotiate long-term funding arrangements for public dental services.
Under the NHRA, the state and territory governments have committed to providing eligible patients public hospital services free-of-charge, with priority determined based on clinical need.

Additionally, the Government funds the Child Dental Benefits Scheme (CDBS). The CDBS is a means tested program that provides eligible children up to $1052 in benefits over a two-calendar year period. Since the CDBS program commenced on 1 January 2014, it has provided $2.9 billion in benefits for 48 million services to 3.4 million eligible Australian children. Under the program, over 95% of services are bulk billed with no out-of-pocket for patients.
The Government continues to work with states and territories on ways of improving access to dental services for all Australians.

Health Ministers have made dental policy reform a priority and are considering funding reform options. This reform work is being supported by a National Dental Reform Oversight Group (Oversight Group), as established by the Health Chief Executives' Forum. The Oversight Group is considering options for consideration by governments regarding sustainable, longer-term funding arrangements that better meet community needs.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler

subdebateinfo.title: Health Care: Drug and Alcohol Services

p.span: Health Care: Drug and Alcohol Services
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence to the Minister for Health and Aged Care, the Hon Mark Butler MP, regarding a petition for funding for drug and alcohol program at the Murray Mallee General Practice Network (Petition Number: EN4399). I am responding as the Acting Minister for Health and Aged Care.

The Australian Government is committed to reducing the impacts of drug and alcohol use on individuals, families and communities through the Drug and Alcohol Program. This includes an investment of more than $870 million over four years (from 1 July 2022) to support drug and alcohol treatment services and prevention, research and communication.

Funding of up to $27.9 million (GST exclusive) over two years (2022-23 to 2023-24) has been committed to targeted alcohol and other drug treatment services in identified areas of need. As part of this funding, $1.04 million (GST exclusive) has been committed to continue to provide drug and alcohol treatment to support the community in the Murray Mallee region of South Australia, through the Murray Mallee General Practice Network.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Acting Minister for Health and Aged Care, Ms Wells

subdebateinfo.title: Rural and Regional Health Services: Pharmacy Services

p.span: Rural and Regional Health Services: Pharmacy Services
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 7 November 2022 to the Minister for Health and Aged Care, the Hon Mark Butler MP, regarding Petition EN4410 requesting to amend eligibility criteria for the Rural Locum Assistance Program (RLAP). I am responding as the Acting Minister for Health and Aged Care.
The Petition seeks changes to allow consideration of extenuating circumstances for placements that would enable pharmacies to remain open where they might otherwise close.

RLAP specifically provides locums to backfill for an employed health professional while they are absent on professional development training or on leave. This supports retention of the rural workforce and a pharmacy owner can request the assistance of RLAP while they take Continuing Professional Development or annual leave. The program is not a source of locums to cover workforce vacancies. There are, however, a number of private agencies that may be able to provide locums for this purpose.
Further, the Australian Government recognises the pressures of health workforce vacancies on services access in rural areas.

The Government is determined to improve access to healthcare for all Australians and recognises the barriers people in rural and remote Australia face in accessing care. The 2023-24 Budget delivers critical funding for urgent needs and lays the foundations for longer-term reform. More information on the 2023-24 Budget is available on the Department of Health and Aged Care's website at www.health.gov.au.

Alternatively, pharmacies facing workforce pressures can seek support funded by the Government. Rural Workforce Agencies (RWAs) in each state and the Northern Territory, under the Rural Health Workforce Support Activity deliver a range of activities aimed at improving the access, quality, and sustainability of the regional, rural, and remote health workforce. RWAs can support the recruitment of health workforce into vacancies, and contact details for each jurisdiction can be found of the department's website by searching 'Rural Health Workforce Support Activity'.

Further, Primary Health Networks (PHNs) are also funded by the Government to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of health services for people and increasing access and quality support for people. Part of this includes working closely with providers to build health workforce capacity. Contact details for pharmacies seeking support from their local PHN may be found on the department's website by searching 'Primary Health Network (PHN) locator map'.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Acting Minister for Health and Aged Care, Ms Wells
Medicare
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 7 November 2022 regarding petition EN4416 and 17 May 2023 regarding petition EN4849, both regarding access to bulk billed healthcare. I apologise for the significant delay in responding.

The 2023-24 Budget provided a historic $6.1 billion investment in Medicare to lay the foundations for significant reform to general practice and primary care for all Australians. It delivers critical funding to meet urgent healthcare needs of today, while starting reforms to build a stronger Medicare for future generations. The Budget responds to the recommendations of the Strengthening Medicare Taskforce and takes the key steps needed to address the many pressing challenges in Australia's healthcare system. Key measures which will strengthen Medicare include:
$3.5 billion investment to triple bulk billing incentives to support free GP consultations for children, the elderly and other Commonwealth concession card holders.
$1.5 billion investment in an indexation boost to Medicare rebates
$951 million to improve digital health technologies
$236.5 million for the new MyMedicare system that will enable health teams to provide more tailored care
$1.6 billion saving to patients by enabling patients to buy two months' worth of medicine in a single prescription

A range of additional measures to build a bigger health and aged care workforce that is skilled, diverse, motivated, well-distributed and sustainable and has all clinicians working to the full extent of their skills and training.
Further information on these changes can be found in the Building a Stronger Medicare Budget fact sheet at www.health.gov.au by using 'Building a stronger Medicare Budget 2023-24'.

To support GPs to bulk bill their patients the Australian Government provides a bulk billing incentive for services for patients with a Commonwealth Concession Card and children under 16 years of age. From 1 November 2023, the bulk billing incentives will be tripled for the most common GP consultation items, that is:
all face-to-face general attendance consultations more than six minutes in length
all telehealth general attendance consultations which are between six and 20 minutes in length (known as Level B consultations)
longer telehealth phone and video general attendance consultations where a patient is registered through MyMedicare.
Around 11.6 million people will be eligible for these new incentives.

The Government also recognises that unforeseen out-of-pocket expenses can add to the distress of those who suffer serious or unexpected illnesses and provides assistance to patients who incur high out-of-pocket medical expenses through both the Original Medicare Safety Net and the Extended Medicare Safety Net (EMSN).

The EMSN provides benefits of up to 80% of out-of-pocket costs for eligible out-of-hospital services once an annual threshold of out-of-pocket expenses is reached, subject to any EMSN caps that may be in place. The current EMSN threshold for Commonwealth Concession Card holders and Family Tax Benefit Part A participants in 2023 is $770.30 and the non-concessional threshold is $2,414.00. Thresholds are indexed annually on 1 January in line with the Consumer Price Index. Both safety nets are calendar year programs, renewing on 1 January each year. More information is available at www.servicesaustralia.gov.au/medicare-safety-nets.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Medicare
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 7 November 2022 regarding petition EN4418, requesting the Australian Government increase the Medicare rebate for GP consultation items. I apologise for the significant delay in responding.

The 2023-24 Budget provided a historic $6.1 billion investment in Medicare to lay the foundations for significant reform to general practice and primary care for all Australians. It delivers critical funding to meet urgent healthcare needs of today, while starting reforms to build a stronger Medicare for future generations. The Budget responds to the recommendations of the Strengthening Medicare Taskforce and takes the key steps needed to address the many pressing challenges in Australia's healthcare system. Key measures which will strengthen Medicare include:
$3.5 billion investment to triple bulk billing incentives to support free GP consultations for children, the elderly and other Commonwealth concession card holders
$1.5 billion investment in an indexation boost to Medicare rebates
$951 million to improve digital health technologies
$236.5 million for the new MyMedicare system that will enable health teams to provide more tailored care.
$1.6 billion saving to patients by enabling patients to buy two months' worth of medicine in a single prescription

a range of additional measures to build a bigger health and aged care workforce that is skilled, diverse, motivated, well-distributed and sustainable, and has all clinicians working to the full extent of their skills and training.
Further information on these changes can be found in the Building a Stronger Medicare Budget fact sheet at www.health.gov.au by using the search term 'Building a stronger Medicare Budget 2023-24'.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Dementia
Dear Chair

I refer to your correspondence of 7 November 2022 to the Minister for Health and Aged Care, the Hon Mark Butler, regarding petition EN4420 which seeks to initiate plasma exchange clinics to provide life-saving therapies and research for those living with dementia. This matter has been referred to me as the Minister for Aged Care.

The Australian Government acknowledges the significant and increasing impact dementia has on our community as the second leading cause of death and disease burden in Australia.
