In response to this, the Government, along with state and territory governments, are working together to develop a 10-year joint National Dementia Action Plan (Action Plan) to put people living with dementia, their families, and carers at the centre of action on dementia.

The Action Plan has a vision where Australians understand dementia—people living with dementia and their carers have the best quality of life possible. The Action Plan will include broad objectives to support this vision, including timely diagnosis, early intervention support and post-diagnostic support for people living with dementia, their families and carers. The Action Plan will also consider the need for ongoing research into dementia to improve treatment, care and quality of life for people living with dementia.

The public consultation for the Action Plan was highly successful with more than 1000 submissions received, with work underway to ensure that the final Action Plan reflects the diverse needs, experiences and requirements of people impacted by dementia. These actions will build on the existing work underway by the Government to support people in accessing timely and accessible services and supports.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Acting Minister for Health and Aged Care, Ms Wells
Food Labelling
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 7 November 2022 to the Minister for Health and Aged Care, the Hon Mark Butler MP, regarding a petition for updating the laws for packaged food labelling (Petition number: EN4423). I am responding as the Acting Minister for Health and Aged Care.
The request asks the House of Representatives to put forward laws that require food manufacturers to label packaged foods as suitable or not suitable for vegetarian and vegan diets.

Food Standards Australia New Zealand (FSANZ) is the independent statutory authority responsible for the development and maintenance of the Australia New Zealand Food Standards Code (Code) which sets out the legal requirements for food produced or imported for sale in Australia and New Zealand.

The Code requires labels of foods for sale in Australia to contain ingredient lists and a Nutrition Information Panel. There is currently no requirement for vegetarian or vegan labelling because the standards in the Code are primarily aimed at protecting public health and safety, for example requiring declaration of allergens. When making decisions about the information to be provided on a food label, the Food Regulation System has endorsed a food labelling hierarchy as part of the Policy Guideline on Food Labelling to Support Consumers to Make Informed Healthy Food Choices (2020). The food labelling hierarchy gives first priority to information related to food safety, followed by information regarding preventive health and consumer values issues as a third priority.

Even though the Code does not require vegan or vegetarian labelling, food manufacturers can choose to voluntarily provide information about the vegan and vegetarian status of foods on food labels. These types of representations are subject to relevant consumer laws in Australia, which prohibits misleading or deceptive conduct and false or misleading representations about a food offered for sale.

Regarding food additives, the Code requires ingredients, including food additives, to be declared in the statement of ingredients on the label of most packaged foods (with some exemptions). Food additives are required to be identified by their class name (e.g. 'colour') followed by the name of the food additive or the food additive number. The food additive numbers are based on an international system, set out in the Codex General Standard for Food Additives.

A full list of food additive names and code numbers is available on the FSANZ website at: www.foodstandards.gov.au/consumer/labelling/Pages/Labelling-of-food-additives.aspx. Food additives are the only ingredients that can be listed using a numerical code.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Acting Minister for Health and Aged Care, Ms Wells
Food Labelling
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 8 November 2023 to the Minister for Health and Aged Care, the Hon Mark Butler MP, regarding petition number EN4459. I am responding as the Acting Minister for Health and Aged Care.
The petitioner requests that the House of Representatives investigate and ban all wording such as 'meat' from vegan products, noting that these can be misleading to consumers.

Australian food and consumer laws are designed to provide consumers with the information they need to make an informed choice. It is unlawful for a business to make a representation that is false or misleading.

Food Standards Australia New Zealand is the independent statutory authority responsible for the development and maintenance of the Australia New Zealand Food Standards Code (Code). The Code sets out the legal requirements for food produced or imported for sale in Australia and New Zealand. The Code requires the name of a food to be a name or description that is sufficient to indicate the true nature of the food (Standard 1.2.2, section 2). The Code also allows for the use of a food name with additional descriptors (Standard 1.1.1, subsection 13(4)). For example, the descriptor 'soy' for soy sausage makes it clear to the consumer that the food they are purchasing is not a sausage made from meat.

The Code also requires ingredient information and a nutrition information panel on most packaged foods to assist consumers make an informed choice about the food they are purchasing and how it compares with other products.

The Australian Consumer Law (ACL) is enforced by the independent statutory authority, the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC), as well as state and territory consumer protection agencies under a 'one law, multiple regulator' model. Amongst other things, the ACL prohibits businesses from engaging in conduct that is misleading or deceptive or likely to mislead or deceive, or from making a representation that is false or misleading about the quality, quantity, composition or origin of food products.

Whether the labelling of a plant-based substitute product may be misleading under the ACL depends on the overall impression conveyed to a reasonable consumer by the labelling and packaging. Any such consideration takes into account matters such as specific statements made and images used and their relative prominence, placement and size, and does not hinge on the use of any particular word (such as 'meat') or any particular image.

The ACCC has previously considered the labelling of some plant-based substitute products when these issues have been raised with them. In each case the ACCC considered that a court would view the overall impression conveyed by the labelling of these products as unlikely to mislead an ordinary consumer. At most, it may create a sense of confusion, which the courts have found not to breach the ACL.

Anyone can make a report to the ACCC, or their local state or territory consumer protection agency, about a specific product or advertisement they consider is misleading. The ACCC uses information received from reports from the public, as well as other sources of intelligence, to inform its enforcement and compliance work.

The ACCC undertakes its compliance and enforcement work pursuant to its Compliance and Enforcement Policy. As an economy-wide regulator, the ACCC focuses on issues that have the potential to seriously harm the competitive process or result in widespread consumer or business detriment. Where an issue or conduct is more localised (such as conduct engaged in by a business that only operates in a single state or territory), it is more appropriate to report these to the local state or territory consumer protection agency.

Individuals also have a private right of action under the ACL and can apply to a court to seek damages against a business, if they consider they have been affected by the business engaging in alleged misleading or deceptive conduct.

I note the petition requests an investigation of labelling systems for these meat-alternative products. The petitioner may be aware that the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee undertook an inquiry into the definitions of meat and other animal products in Australia. Their report, tabled in February 2022, includes a number of recommendations that relate to the labelling of plant-based meat alternatives. The Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry is currently working with other agencies to finalise the Australian Government response to the inquiry. Both the report, and the Government response once available, can be viewed at www.aph.gov.au by searching 'definitions of meat'.

I can advise that labelling of plant-based alternatives to meat and dairy products has also been examined through the joint Australia-New Zealand Food Regulatory System. In 2019, the then Australia and New Zealand Ministerial Forum on Food Regulation considered work on misleading descriptions for food. Ministers agreed that plant-based foods mimicking animal-based foods are adequately regulated under the current labelling requirements and consumer and fair-trading laws.

Earlier work through the Food Regulatory System in 2016 considered dairy substitute beverages, which included consideration of the use of the word 'milk' for these products. Ministers similarly agreed at that time that these beverages are adequately regulated by current permissions in the Food Standards Code.

The Government strongly affirms the importance of clear food labelling. In May 2022, the Government made an election commitment to improve existing regulations to deliver accurate and clear food labelling for products so that consumers can make informed choices. The Government will consider the views of all sectors and the effectiveness of existing regulations as it takes this work forward.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Acting Minister for Health and Aged Care, Ms Wells
Rural and Regional Health Services
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 11 November 2022 to the Minister for Health and Aged care, the Hon Mark Butler MP, regarding petition EN4477 requesting the waiver of any consultation for the implementation of the Dialysis Treatment Buses in Far West New South Wales (NSW) measure announced in the October 2022-23 Budget. I am responding as the Acting Minister for Health and Aged Care.

The Government recognises the importance of improved and timely access to dialysis treatments in regional and remote areas of the country. This measure will help to reduce the distance patients have to travel to receive dialysis, thereby ensuring they receive the care they need and enabling them to remain on Country and connected with their communities.

The Australian Government is committed to achieving better health outcomes for First Nations people and key to this is pursuing and delivering on its commitments in a manner that gives practical effect to the Priority Reforms of the National Agreement on Closing the Gap (National Agreement).

Under Priority Reforms One and Two of the National Agreement in particular, the Government has committed to pursuing formal partnerships and shared decision-making arrangements and to building the community-controlled sector.

To ensure the measure is implemented in line with the National Agreement and Priority Reforms One and Two, it is crucial that robust engagement is undertaken with key delivery agents, particularly the local Aboriginal Community Controlled Health Service, Maari Ma Health Aboriginal Corporation (Maari Ma).

This will ensure Maari Ma's views, along with those of NSW Health, guide the design of the measure so that it both meets the needs and aspirations of communities in Far West NSW and ensures the ongoing sustainability of any dialysis service in the region.

I am advised officials from the Department of Health and Aged Care will be meeting with Maari Ma, NSW Health, and representatives from local communities later this month and potentially into August to finalise proposed delivery arrangements. I also understand the Assistant Minister for Indigenous Health, Senator the Hon Malarndirri McCarthy will also seek to engage with representatives from local communities in the July meetings.
I am confident this investment will make a real and positive difference in the lives of people with end-stage kidney disease in the Far West NSW community and surrounding areas.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Acting Minister for Health and Aged Care, Ms Wells
Skilled Migration Program
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 6 February 2023 enclosing Petition EN4581, with 5,270 signatures, concerning the number of on hand Skilled Regional Visa (subclass 887) visa applications.

The Australian Government recognises the important and valuable contribution regional visa holders, including subclass 489 visa holders, make in closing labour and skills gaps and supporting businesses and communities through their commitment to living, working and studying in regional areas of Australia.

Reducing the number of on hand visa applications, including in the subclass 887 caseload, is a priority for the Government. The Government appreciates that all applicants seek to have their visa applications finalised as quickly as possible.

While subclass 887 visa applicants already hold visas with work rights, the Government is actively seeking to address this situation and has dedicated resources to continue progress made on reducing visa backlogs. To that end, over 10,000 subclass 887 visas have been granted by the Department of Home Affairs since 1 July 2022.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN4581 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
Australian Currency
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN4638—House to enshrine the use of cash in law.

Australia has a well-functioning payments system offering various payment methods, including the use of cash. The Government has committed to ensuring that Australians have continued access to cash. This commitment is contained in the Government's recently released Strategic Plan for the Payments System—https://treasury.gov.au/publication/p2023-404960.

The Australian Government understands that new technologies and processes can raise concerns for citizens, and I acknowledge the petition's concerns regarding a potential Australian central bank digital currency (CBDCfdie). As part of our commitment to modernise the Australian financial system to keep up with an increasingly digital economy, the Government is working with the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) to explore the benefits and risks of a CBDC. This includes the current pilot being run by the RBA and the Digital Finance Cooperative Research Centre, and is in line with the work of governments and central banks around the world.

At this time, no decision has been made to issue an Australian CBDC. However, I understand citizens' concerns about government oversight, programmable money, and monetary policy. These risks are not inherent to a CBDC but would result from specific design choices and features. I can assure you that the research work being conducted by the Government and the RBA is guided by principles of privacy protection.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Treasurer, Dr Chalmers
Coeliac Disease: Defence Recruitment
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 6 February 2023 regarding Petition EN4641 which seeks to revise the employment regulations precluding people with coeliac disease from joining the Australian Defence Force (ADF).

Defence's medical entry standards govern the necessary health standards required of military personnel to meet operational requirements. These standards are set to ensure members are able to perform their duties safely in a deployed or operational setting. They also prevent members placing themselves or others at risk, such that the operation or mission may be compromised.

An individual diagnosed with coeliac disease must adhere to a strict lifelong gluten free diet. This is currently the only management for coeliac disease as any exposure to gluten has the potential to cause small bowel damage and other serious health consequences. Consequently, current medical entry standards for the ADF excludes applicants who have coeliac disease. Considerations for this exclusion include the dietary restrictions and inability to take certain medications. There is also increased risk of incapacity and complications requiring medical treatment for those with coeliac disease which may not be available when deployed on operations.

While an individual is able to manage their diet in a domestic environment, the ADF may be unable to guarantee a suitable diet during military exercises, operations, or service onboard a sea-going vessel. Simply procuring gluten-free ration packs does not offer sufficient mitigation to protect an individual with coeliac disease. In the case of vegetarians, if food options are exhausted, individuals can still obtain sufficient nutrition from non-vegetarian options. For individuals with coeliac disease this is not the case, and could place the individual at risk of harm due to the potential exposure to gluten.

That said, Defence has retained members with coeliac disease who were diagnosed while in service, with appropriate employment and deployment restrictions. These decisions are made on a case by case basis, considering the member's condition stability, time since diagnosis, symptoms and dietary compliance.

The recently released Defence Strategic Review recommends the Government review its recruitment framework to improve eligibility and the Government has agreed to this recommendation. This review will necessarily include matters such as how coeliac disease is dealt with at the time of recruitment.
Yours faithfully,
from the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Mr Keogh
Skilled Migration Program
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 6 February 2023 enclosing Petition EN4645, with 53 signatures, concerning a request to reduce processing times for the Skilled Employer Sponsored Regional (provisional) (subclass 494) visa.

The Australian Government recognises the important and valuable contribution skilled regional visa holders, including subclass 494 visa holders, have made in closing labour and skills gaps and supporting businesses and communities particularly during the COVID-19 pandemic through their commitment to living, working and studying in regional areas of Australia.

The Australian Government is committed to clearing visa backlogs. Strong progress has been made. As announced at the Jobs and Skills Summit on 1 and 2 September 2022, a one-off investment of $36.1 million has been made by the Government to fund an extra 500 positions to support temporary and migration visa processing undertaken by the Department of Home Affairs to reduce on hand visa applications, including in the subclass 494 caseload. We have finalised 5.42 million temporary and migration visa applications since 1 July 2022.

There is more work to do to further reduce processing times. As the Department continues to uplift staff capacity and capability, implement new policy settings and streamline processes, processing times will trend down.

Skilled visa applications are processed according to Government policy priorities, which are outlined in Ministerial Direction No. 100 and commenced in October 2022. More information is available from the Department's website at: https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/visas/getting- a-visa/visa-processing-times/skilled-visa-processing-priorities.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN4645 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
Australian Currency
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN4646—The King's image to be included on the Australian $5 note.

The Reserve Bank has decided to update the $5 banknote to feature a new design that honours the culture and history of the First Australians. The other side of the $5 banknote will continue to feature the Australian Parliament. This decision by the Reserve Bank Board follows consultation with the Australian Government, which supports this change. The Reserve Bank will consult with First Australians in designing the $5 banknote.

The new banknote will take a number of years to be designed and printed. In the meantime, the current $5 banknote, which features a portrait of Queen Elizabeth II, will continue to be issued. It will be able to be used even after the new banknote is issued.

Consistent with past practice, Australian coins will bear the effigy of King Charles III. The process to change the effigy on the obverse of Australian coins from Queen Elizabeth II to the King may take up to 12 months. Coins featuring King Charles III will circulate alongside coins bearing the effigy of Queen Elizabeth II.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Treasurer, Dr Chalmers
Waste Management and Recycling
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 6 March 2023 regarding Petition Number EN4664 about the removal of all non-biodegradable soft plastics in packaging.

The Australian Government is committed to being a leader in resource management and recovery and achieving greater sustainability. Driving a circular economy approach for packaging will see our valuable materials reused, while reducing the environmental harm and carbon emissions that come from a linear production-to-landfill approach. We cannot achieve a circular economy or solve the plastics challenge without transforming Australia's packaging to be designed sustainably, collected efficiently, and recycled into valuable materials and new products.

Reducing and responsibly managing Australia's plastic waste is a priority for the government. In the short term, my department is working closely with industry to see soft plastic collection and recycling systems restored as soon as possible. Medium to long term solutions will include improved packaging design to ensure packaging materials are easier to recycle, new approaches to how packaging materials are collected and managed, and new technologies to recycle soft plastics back into food grade packaging or other marketable plastic products. The issues facing soft plastic collection and recycling are unfortunate, but they are temporary. Coles, Woolworths, and Aldi have released a roadmap that outlines the pathway to resume instore collection, which can be found on the supermarkets' websites. Industry has a lead role in improving the sustainability of plastics they use, and the government will continue to support them in delivering solutions.

In October 2022, all Environment Ministers agreed to reform the regulation of packaging by 2025 to ensure that all packaging available in Australia is designed to be recovered, reused, recycled, and reprocessed safely in line with circular economy principles.

This reform is an opportunity to mandate obligations for industry and provide a framework to support and monitor industry progress against design and circularity objectives. I am committed to working with industry and the states and territories to address barriers to achieving the targets and to have a new fit-for-purpose regulatory scheme for packaging in place by 2025.

The government is also supporting industry through infrastructure investment under the Recycling Modernisation Fund, fast-tracking the phase-out of problematic and unnecessary single-use plastics, and supporting households to recycle packaging correctly using the Australasian Recycling Label.

There are many factors to be considered in the design and use of plastics to reduce the impact on the environment. While there is increasing interest from industry and consumers about biodegradable plastics, the term biodegradable can be misleading by implying packaging will safely degrade outside of a processing system. Some biodegradable plastics release toxic components into the environment as they degrade, fragmenting or breaking up into microplastics that further contribute to plastic pollution. There is also no requirement for products labelled as biodegradable to specify the conditions and timeframe within which the material must break down.

In contrast, compostable plastic packaging certified to Australian Standard AS4736 or AS5810 must degrade or break down within relatively short timeframes and comply with important quality and ecotoxicity criteria. Certified compostable packaging can also offer value as part of a circular economy as an alternative for single-use plastics for facilitating the recovery of food waste where it is accepted through food organic recovery systems.

It is important to recognise that there are many circumstances where recyclable plastic packaging will have a preferable outcome over biodegradable or certified compostable packaging. For example, conventional plastic packaging which can be recycled and reused multiple times in new packaging and other products has an improved life cycle outcome over biodegradable plastic which can take years to degrade and cannot be reused.

To reduce the environmental impact of soft plastic packaging it is essential that industry both reduces the use of plastic and adopts sustainable design principles. A central pillar of the government's reform of packaging regulation will ensure industry complies with obligations for the sustainable design of soft plastic packaging. These requirements could include the use of mono-materials, an overall reduction of plastic use, only using ink and labels compatible with recycling processes, increasing the use of recycled content, and adopting the Australasian Recycling Label. The Australian Packaging Covenant Organisation's Sustainable Packaging Guidelines and the international CEFLEX soft plastics guidelines are currently available for industry to use as best practice models for soft plastics design.
We are undertaking a comprehensive and ambitious program to address this significant national challenge in close collaboration with industry and state and territory governments.
Thank you again for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for the Environment and Water, Ms Plibersek
Superannuation
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN4665 on changes to annual lodgements of the transfer balance account report (TBAR) for self-managed super funds (SMSFs). Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

The law provides that the responsibility for the administration of Australia's superannuation and taxation system rests with the Australian Taxation Office (ATO). Given that the ATO is an independent body, the operation of certain aspects of the regulation of SMSFs is conducted by the ATO. This includes the aspects in relation to which the petition has raised concerns. Neither the Treasurer nor the Assistant Treasurer can legally intervene in the ATO' s exercise of its statutory powers. This ensures that its decisions and actions are, and are seen to be, free from political influence.

The ATO has advised that Australians who hold their retirement savings in an SMSF are not required to complete a TBAR unless they have a retirement phase event that impacts a member's transfer balance account. For example, the most common events to report involve starting a pension or death benefit income stream, or commuting a pension into a lump sum superannuation payment. This means that SMSFs do not need to complete a quarterly TBAR where one has previously been completed at the commencement of a pension, and the only transactions involve ongoing pension payments or investment earnings.

The ATO has also explained it consulted widely before revising the administrative arrangements for SMSF TBAR reporting. Overall, there was strong support for streamlining TBAR reporting for all SMSFs, as it is expected to reduce complexity for professionals and their clients.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer and Minister for Financial Services, Mr Jones
Parliamentary Petitions: Digital Platforms
Dear Ms Templeman

I refer to your correspondence of 6 March 2023 concerning Petition EN4674 which calls for the House of Representatives to make restriction, deletion, demotion, hiding or unpublishing of any fair and factual promotion of a Parliamentary e-petition by media or social media companies a contempt of Parliament. I apologise for the delay in responding.

The Australian Government is committed to protecting and promoting the rights and freedoms of Australians, including freedom of speech and expression. These rights and freedoms underpin Australia's democracy and the Government continues to work to protect and promote these rights and freedoms.

As private companies, digital platforms are able to make decisions about the content on their platforms in line with their Terms of Service. Digital platforms often have Terms of Service and community standards that determine how users can interact with each other and how the content on their platforms will be moderated. Many digital platforms use technology to automatically detect and remove content that violates their Terms of Service and policies.

If someone is concerned with a decision made by a platform regarding the removal, moderation or banning of content, they may wish to contact the platform directly to lodge a complaint. Many of the major digital platforms have complaints mechanisms or systems to appeal decisions.

On 11 November 2022, the Treasurer, the Hon Jim Chalmers MP, and the Assistant Minister for Competition, Charities and Treasury, the Hon Dr Andrew Leigh MP, released the ACCC's 5th interim report for the Digital Platforms Services Inquiry (the report). The report recommends, in part, that the Government introduce specific consumer measures to improve the dispute resolution processes of digital platforms.

The Treasury undertook a public consultation process on the recommendations contained in the report through a consultation paper released in late December 2022. The Government is now considering the outcomes of this consultation process and feedback provided by stakeholders including in relation to social media dispute resolution mechanisms.
I thank the Committee for bringing these concerns to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Ms Rowland
Defence Recruitment
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 6 March 2023, regarding Petition EN4715, which seeks to change legislation regarding the acceptance of individuals with medical conditions such as attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder and anaphylaxis into the Australian Defence Force (ADF).

Defence' s medical entry standards govern the necessary health standards required of military personnel to meet operational demands. These standards are set to ensure members are able to perform their duties safely in an operational setting, domestically or overseas, and which may necessitate deployment to austere and poorly supported environments. These standards seek to prevent members' medical conditions causing undue harm or risk to themselves or others, or compromising the successful achievement of military missions.

The recently released Defence Strategic Review recommends the Government review its recruitment framework to improve eligibility and the Government has agreed to this recommendation. This review will necessarily include matters such as how attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder and anaphylaxis is dealt with at the time of recruitment.
I trust this information is of value to the Standing Committee on Petitions.
Yours faithfully,
from the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Mr Keogh
Sponsored Parent (Temporary) Visa
Dear Ms Templeman,
Thank you for your correspondence of 27 March 2023 enclosing Petition EN4798, with 2,627 signatures, concerning the annual places and processing times for Parent visas.

Family migration is an important element of Australia's migration system, allowing Australian citizens and permanent residents to reunite with their family members and contribute to stronger social cohesion outcomes. It is recognised that immigrant parents can make valuable social contributions to their families and local communities.

It has been the longstanding practice of successive Governments to manage the orderly delivery of Migration Program outcomes against planning levels. The Australian Government sets the size and composition of the Migration Program each year through the Government's Budget process, following consultations with state and territory governments, business and community groups and the wider public.

The permanent Migration Program is set with Australia's immediate and longer-term economic and social needs as primary considerations. Immigration policy has enduring effects on many dimensions of Australian life. Getting the policy settings right is critical to maximising community wellbeing, and the relative merits of any policy must be assessed against a broader context that takes into account all the relevant dimensions of societal wellbeing.

Processing times for Parent visas are impacted by a range of factors, including the number of places the Government allocates to a program each year, and the level of demand for each visa category. High volumes of Parent visa application lodgements, which for a number of years exceeded annual migration program planning levels set by successive Governments, have resulted in extended processing times.

Additionally, the COVID-19 pandemic significantly affected the availability of key assessment services, such as health checks. This impacted applicants' ability to meet visa criteria, and disrupted the Department of Home Affairs' visa processing services.

The time taken to process visa applications can also vary according to the individual circumstances of each case. The quality and completeness of applications, applicants' responsiveness to requests for information, and the complexities often involved in assessing character, health and security requirements, may all influence processing times.

The processing of Family visa application backlogs, particularly in the Parent program, remains a priority for the Government. Reducing the Parent visa backlog is a complex issue and will require a number of strategies to be successful. The lengthy processing times for Parent visas was one of the key issues raised in public submissions to the 2021-22 Senate inquiry into the 'Efficacy, fairness, timeliness and costs of the processing and granting of visa classes which provide for or allow for family and partner reunions'.

Among a range of other strategies under consideration, the Government has recognised the impact of the above factors on processing times and in the October 2022 Budget announced an increase in the migration planning level for Parent visas from 4,500 in 2021-22 to 8,500 places in 2022-23.

On 2 September 2022, the Hon Clare O'Neil MP, Minister for Home Affairs and Minister for Cyber Security, announced a comprehensive review of the purpose, structure and objectives of Australia's migration system to ensure it meets the challenges of the coming decade. Further information about the review can be found on the Department's website at: https://www.homeaffairs.gov.au/help-and-support/how-to-engage-us/consultations/australias-22-23-migration-program. The future direction of the Family visa program, including Parent visas, will be informed as part of this review.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN4798 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
Sepsis
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 27 March 2023 regarding petition EN4805 which suggests the provision of routine sepsis screening for children and other at-risk Australians.

The Australian Government shares the concerns raised in this petition about the impacts of sepsis on the Australian community. The Government agrees that there is a genuine need for improved awareness and understanding, early detection and better treatment of sepsis, particularly for First Nations people who are disproportionally affected by sepsis.

To address this issue, in September 2019 the Government committed $1.5 million to the National Sepsis Program (NSP) to deliver a broad range of research activities and other measures to improve the awareness, diagnosis and the management of sepsis. The NSP was led and coordinated by the Australian Commission on Safety and Quality in Health Care (Commission) in partnership with Sepsis Australia through The George Institute for Global Health (TGI).

The aim of the NSP is to assist in raising awareness of the key symptoms of sepsis, resulting in earlier presentation to health care services, and a subsequent reduced burden of disease and mortality arising from sepsis complications. It further aims to improve the recognition of sepsis in all health care settings and ensuring appropriate care for sepsis survivors.

As part of the NSP, the Commission developed a new Sepsis National Clinical Care Standard, which was launched on 30 June 2022. This clinical care standard provides guidance to consumers, clinicians, and healthcare services to help ensure that sepsis is recognised early, and patients receive coordinated, best practice care. In addition to this standard, the NSP includes a further seven projects assisting to achieve the NSP's aim. More information is available at: www.safetyandguality.gov.au/our-work/national-sepsis-program.

The Government has committed to providing a further $2.1 million over two years from 2022-2023 for the NSP Extension. This additional funding will build on the first phase of the NSP as well as delivering additional projects.
The projects under the NSP Extension include:
targeted training for undergraduate health programs and health professionals
a comprehensive national awareness campaign
building capacity and ensuring appropriate care for sepsis survivors
the development and publication of data collection tools to drive improvements in sepsis care
improving the recognition of sepsis for First Nations peoples.

The development of targeted sepsis education resources for undergraduate health programs and health professionals across primary and acute care settings is an important component of the NSP Extension. It will include sepsis subject curriculum development for medical, nursing and allied health undergraduate program. It will also include the development and post-implementation evaluation of training models and education resources to ensure a greater understanding of sepsis recognition and management. This education will assist the Australian health workforce to become better trained in the diagnosis and screening of sepsis, ultimately leading to better health outcomes for patients.

Given their longstanding expertise of sepsis in Australia, the Commission will continue to work in partnership with TGI and Sepsis Australia under the NSP Extension. The Commission will also work with relevant stakeholders, including but not limited to, consumer organisations, consumers, First Nations organisations, researchers, health professionals, hospitals and health care services, and state and territory government agencies to deliver on these activities.

The Government is also committed to health and medical research and invests in Australian research and its translation into practice to ensure Australia's entire health system is prepared for current and future challenges. The Government provides direct support for health and medical research through the complementary Medical Research Future Fund (MRFF) and the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC).

From inception in 2015 to 31 March 2023, the MRFF has invested $21.22 million, through eight research grants, on sepsis. One of these research grants, awarded to Flinders University, has a particular focus on equitable access to full blood evaluation testing at the point-of-care in remote primary health, providing fast access to blood test results to help early diagnosis of sepsis or other infections. More information on the awarded grants is available at www.health.gov.au/ resources/publications/medical-research-future-fund-mrff-grant-recipients.
In addition to this MRFF funding, between 2000 and 2022, the NHMRC has expended $78.1 million to research relevant to sepsis.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Vaccination
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 17 May 2023 regarding Petition EN4810 asking the House of Representatives to ban messenger ribonucleic acid (mRNA) vaccines in Australia or to introduce a two-year moratorium so that further safety testing can be done.

The safety of the Australian population has always been the Australian Government's highest priority and we strongly support immunisation as a safe and effective public-health measure. The COVID-19 vaccine program's primary goal is to minimise the risk of severe disease, including hospitalisation and death. For this reason, decisions regarding COVID-19 vaccines are based on the expert medical advice from the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation (ATAGI) and from the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA), the national medicines regulator.

I can assure you that the COVID-19 vaccines available in Australia have received the same high level of scrutiny as other prescription medicines and vaccines. The TGA, part of the Department of Health and Aged Care, has comprehensively evaluated each of the COVID-19 vaccines to ensure that they meet Australia's high standards of safety, 'quality and efficacy prior to their approval for use and inclusion in the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods (ARTG). Once included on the ARTG, the TGA continues to closely monitor the safety of these vaccines to ensure the benefits outweigh the risks.

Alongside the TGA, experts in ATAGI closely monitor all current and emerging evidence on COVID-19 vaccines to make recommendations to the Government on whether to include a provisionally approved COVID-19 vaccine in the national vaccine rollout program. This includes safety, efficacy and effectiveness data from clinical trials, data on waning of immunity and local and international epidemiology. A body of evidence from clinical trials and extensive real-world evidence supports the efficacy and safety of mRNA vaccines and has resulted in ATAGI preferencing the use of mRNA vaccines in the COVID-19 vaccination program.

ATAGI will continue to review and update recommendations when required due to a variety of factors, including the evolution of the SARS-CoV-2 virus, changing local and international epidemiology, emergence of real-world safety and efficacy data, and the addition of new vaccine formulations to the program. ATAGI statements on COVID-19 vaccine recommendations, including their rationale for decision making and relevant references, are available at www.health.gov.au using the search term 'ATAGI'.

Due to the nature of the COVID-19 pandemic, all COVID-19 vaccines were initially approved via the provisional approval pathway. A vaccine is provisionally approved by the TGA after a rigorous evaluation process is completed, and the benefits of the vaccine are considered to be much greater than any potential risks.

Since provisional approval was granted, more than 13 billion doses of COVID-19 vaccines have been administered worldwide and over 51.5 million mRNA vaccine doses have been administered in Australia. The safety and efficacy of the COVID-19 vaccines demonstrated in clinical trials has been thoroughly substantiated by real-world use, providing reassurance about the safety of these vaccines. This includes that vaccination is highly effective at preventing serious illness, hospitalisation, and death from COVID-19.

Continued approval is dependent upon the evidence of longer-term efficacy and safety from ongoing clinical trials and post-market assessment. As part of the provisional approval, sponsors are required to continue to submit longer-term evidence to the TGA. As this implies, these studies are continuing to gather data on longer-term safety and effectiveness to complement post-market monitoring and spontaneous adverse event data.

The Moderna COVID-19 Vaccine SPIKEVAX recently received approval from the TGA for full registration. In making this decision, the TGA carefully considered long-term follow-up data from a number of studies that confirmed the safety and efficacy of the vaccine.

The TGA works closely with other regulators around the world to monitor and analyse COVID-19 vaccine safety data covering hundreds of millions of people, and reviews the latest evidence from clinical trials and peer-reviewed medical literature. This information continues to overwhelmingly support the safe and effective use of COVID-19 vaccines. It remains the consensus view of international regulators and health departments that the benefits of COVID-19 vaccination continue to far outweigh the risks.

To support the robust safety monitoring system, the TGA strongly encourages consumers and health professionals to report suspected adverse events, even if there is only a very small likelihood a vaccine was the cause. The easiest way to do this is to submit a report online at www.tga.gov.au and click on 'Report a problem' at the top right of the page, or call the Adverse Medicine Events line on 1300 633 424 to submit a report with the help of a pharmacist.

With large scale COVID-19 vaccination across the Australian population, it is possible that new symptoms or illnesses may coincidentally occur in the days or weeks after vaccination. This does not, however, automatically mean that these have been caused by the vaccine. In many cases, a definite causal relationship is not certain. The adverse event could be coincidental, related to an underlying illness, or due to other factors.

Unfortunately, false and misleading information has been circulating regarding the safety of COVID-19 vaccines. We urge everyone to consider whether their sources of information are credible and trustworthy. The following resources may be helpful:
Comprehensive information on how COVID-19 vaccines are regulated in Australia at www.tga.gov.au/products/covid-19/covid-19-vaccines.
The TGA's fortnightly COVID-19 vaccine safety report at www.tga.gov.au/news/covid-19-vaccine-safety-reports.
Is it true? Get the facts on COVID-19 vaccines at www.health.gov.au/our-work/covid-19-vaccines/is-it-true.
Fact sheets, frequently asked questions and current vaccine safety data from the National Centre for Immunisation Research and Surveillance website at www.ncirs.org.au.

Comprehensive responses by the department, including the TGA, to the Senate Estimates Community Affairs Legislation Committee (transcripts and written answers to Questions on Notice at www.aph.gov.au/Parliamentary Business/Senate estimates/ca.

Australia's response to COVID-19 has been effective, with treatments and vaccines being critical components of Australia's national response and ongoing management strategy to ensure our health system can effectively support COVID-19 patients and continue to provide the necessary population health care.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
National Library of Australia: Trove
Dear Chair
Thank you for your email on behalf of the Standing Committee on Petitions concerning two petitions regarding funding for Trove (EN4825 and PN0557).
As you'd know, the Australian Government has now secured the future for Trove.

From 1 July 2023, the Government will provide funding of $33 million over four years, with indexed ongoing funding of $9.2 million per annum to Trove. This decision follows years of temporary funding under the former Government.
Thank you for your hard work to ensure that millions of Australians can continue to access much of Australia's history through Trove.

Trove supports each of the five pillars of our National Cultural Policy Revive—it is a service that helps us to know ourselves, know each other and it helps the world know us. As a result of the Government's decision, it will now remain accessible into the future.
Thank you again for your help in securing this excellent outcome.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for the Arts, Mr Burke
Disability Support Pension
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your email dated 17 May 2023, concerning the petition relating to the Social Security (Tables for the Assessment of Work related Impairment for Disability Support Pension) Determination 2011 and nurse practitioners (EN4834).

The Determination contains 15 individual Tables designed to assess a person's eligibility for Disability Support Pension (DSP) and are intended to assess a person's loss of functional capacity that affects their ability to work. The Tables are consistent with the World Health Organization's International Classification of Functioning Disability and Health. As such, they are function-based rather than diagnosis-based and describe functional activities, abilities, symptoms and limitations that affect an individual's ability to work.

The new Determination, 'Social Security (Tables for the Assessment of Work-related Impairment for Disability Support Pension) Determination 2023' was registered on 2 March 2023 and took effect on 1 April 2023. The 2023 Impairment Tables built on the previous 2011 Determination, with changes made to improve consistency, address advancements in medical technology and terminology, and aim to ensure there is better clarity regarding eligibility for the DSP.

Prior to the implementation of the 2011 Determination, an Advisory Committee was established that considered the question of diagnosis very carefully. The Committee determined a high level of diagnostic expertise was required for the purposes of DSP and that a medical practitioner is most appropriate for providing a diagnosis. This has not changed and the requirement for a medical practitioner to provide a diagnosis has been retained in the new Determination. This is a consistent requirement across all of the Tables with the exception of Table 9—Intellectual Function due to the type of assessment used for this Table.

Building on the review conducted for the 2011 Determination, a more recent review was conducted prior to the introduction of the 2023 Determination. This process included extensive public consultation with a wide range of stakeholders, disability peak bodies, advocacy groups, medical and other health professionals, Services Australia staff (including the Health Professional Advisory Unit, which includes nurses) who interpret the Impairment Tables and individuals with lived experience of the DSP process.
Consultations were multi-phased allowing for public feedback on both the 2011 Determination and Exposure Draft of the new Determination, which was released in October 2022.

My department's Engage website, a publicly accessible website used for large public consultations, was used for both phases of the consultation process. This was to ensure the views of a broad range of stakeholders were captured. These consultations took place throughout June-July 2021 and October-November 2022. Submissions made to the Senate Inquiry into the Purpose, Intent and Adequacy of DSP (the Senate Inquiry) relevant to the Impairment Tables were also taken into consideration as part of this review.
While there was a very broad and open consultation, nursing peak organisations were not explicitly consulted as part of this process.
Further, medical practitioner diagnostic requirements were not raised as a general issue within the consultation process and review, nor was it a recommendation resulting from the Senate Inquiry.

Regarding concerns about nurse practitioners' role in supporting DSP claims, a diagnosis cannot be provided by a nurse practitioner for the purpose of DSP. However, nurse practitioners have always been able to provide corroborating evidence in support of a patient's claim. This may be in the form of assessments or reports, as well as supporting a medical practitioner to make a diagnosis.

Evidence may be provided by a number of sources however not all sources are referenced by name within the Determination. Examples of types of evidence and health professionals that may provide it are not intended to be prescriptive or exhaustive.

The Australian Government will continue to monitor policy settings of the Determination to ensure they remain appropriate. Input from individuals, groups and organisations is an important part of the policy review process and I acknowledge the concerns that have been raised.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Social Services, Ms Rishworth
First Nations Australians: Retirement
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your email dated 17 May 2023, concerning a petition (EN4835) presented to the House of Representatives on reducing the retirement age for Aboriginal people in Australia.
There is no official retirement age in Australia. Retirement decisions are a matter for each individual.

Age Pension qualification rules are consistent across all population groups, including for Indigenous Australians. Consistent with legislation passed in 2009, the Age Pension qualification age has been increasing by 6 months every 2 years until it reaches 67 years on 1 July 2023. It is currently 66.5 years.

The Age Pension qualifying age is not adjusted for factors which affect a person's longevity such as disability, race, or other social determinants of health. It reflects the accepted Australian community standard where seniors are no longer expected to participate in the labour force, rather than providing pension benefits for a particular number of years.

All Australians under Age Pension age who need support, whether due to unemployment, illness and disability or caring responsibilities, are supported by Australia's social security safety net. This includes payments such as JobSeeker Payment, Carer Payment, Disability Support Pension and Parenting Payment. There are also payments for people undertaking study or an apprenticeship. More information about the different supports available is online at www.servicesaustralia.gov.au.

When people reach 60 years of age, they may also become eligible for extra concessions from state and local government authorities through the Seniors Card. Recipients aged 60 or over are able to access their superannuation tax-free if they are paid from a taxed superannuation fund, which is another concession that benefits many seniors.
I appreciate you bringing this matter to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Social Services, Ms Rishworth

subdebateinfo.title: Universities: Nursing and Midwifery Training Placements

p.span: Universities: Nursing and Midwifery Training Placements
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your email dated 17 May 2023, about a petition (EN4851) presented in the House of Representatives on 9 May 2023 seeking Commonwealth financial support for current nursing and midwifery students while on clinical placements.

Getting more Australians into work remains a key objective for the Government. For those who are studying and need additional help, our income support system is designed to be a safety net. Students who undertake placements as part of their studies may be eligible for student payments such as Youth Allowance or Austudy. To be eligible as a full-time student, a student must be undertaking at least 75 per cent of the normal full-time study load for that course. Practical training or placement off campus can count towards the full-time study load if the educational institution assigns credit points to the placement.

The Government recognises that living on income support payments can be challenging, especially with the increases to the cost of living. As part of the Government's $14.6 billion cost-of-living package announced in the 2023-24 Budget, there are changes to income support payments including:
Increasing working age and student payments, including Youth Allowance and Austudy, by $40 per fortnight.
Increasing the maximum rates of Commonwealth Rent Assistance by 15 per cent, which is the largest increase in more than 30 years.
These changes will commence from 20 September 2023, subject to the passage of legislation.
Beyond income support, the Government is also delivering a number of targeted initiatives and programs to support nursing and midwifery students.

This includes the Higher Education Loan Program (HELP) Debt Reduction for Health Practitioners Program, which will encourage doctors and nurse practitioners to live and work in rural, remote or very remote areas of Australia by waiving indexation provided they meet the eligibility criteria, and reducing their outstanding HELP debt once they have met their obligations to complete the required amount of work.

The Commonwealth is also working in collaboration with all jurisdictions to develop Australia's first National Nursing Workforce Strategy. The Strategy will provide a national-level strategic approach to nursing policy, seeking to fully realise the value of nurses, and the need to ensure that this highly qualified and skilled workforce is supported in Australia. It is expected to look at career pathways and specialisation for nurses across all settings and sectors. Opportunities to participate in consultation on the Strategy will be shared in the Commonwealth Chief Nursing and Midwifery Officer's newsletter: www.health.gov.au/using-our- websites/subscriptions/subscribe-to-our-nursing-and-midwifery-newsletter.

The Government is also providing $25.2 million over 5 years from 2022-23 to establish and deliver a National Nurse and Midwife Health Service (NNMHS), to provide free counselling and health support services for nurses, midwives and nursing and midwifery students, as well as referrals to other support services were required. The Australian Nursing and Midwifery Federation will deliver the NNMHS, and it is anticipated the service will be operational in a phased approach in the second half of 2023.

The Government has also announced funding of $50.2 million over 4 years to expand the future nursing and midwifery workforce through a new Primary Care Nurse and Midwifery Scholarship program, to offer a total of 1,850 post-graduate scholarships for nurses and midwives. These scholarships will support registered nurses and midwives to undertake post-graduate study by supporting registered nurses to become nurse practitioners and midwives to become Eligible Midwives.

In addition to these targeted initiatives and programs, the Government has committed to deliver the Australian Universities Accord through a 12-month review of Australia's higher education system, led by a panel of eminent Australians. The Accord Panel will focus on key priority areas including the affordability of, and contribution arrangements to, higher education. The panel will devise recommendations and performance targets that will improve the quality, accessibility, affordability and sustainability of higher education. The Accord Panel's final report is due to be presented to Government in December 2023.
I appreciate you bringing the experiences and challenges nursing and midwifery students face to my attention. I trust the information provided will be of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Social Services, Ms Rishworth
Environment
Dear Chair

I refer to your correspondence of 17 May 2023 to the Minister for the Environment and Water, the Hon Tanya Plibersek MP regarding Petition EN4856 requesting that the House investigate whether Australia needs to set up an independent panel of experts to oversee dioxins in our food chain and the environment. This matter has been referred to the Minister for Health and Aged Care, the Hon Mark Butler MP. I am responding as the Acting Minister for Health and Aged Care.

Food Standards Australia New Zealand (FSANZ) is an independent statutory agency established by the Food Standards Australia New Zealand Act 1991 operating within the joint Australian and New Zealand food regulation system.

FSANZ has coordinated two national analytical surveys investigating dioxin levels in the Australian food supply—the first in 2004 and most recently as part of the 26th Australian Total Diet Study (ATDS) (2020). These surveys involved the sampling of a broad range of foods from all Australian states and territories.
The 26th ATDS found:
the levels of dioxins in the Australian food supply were generally lower than those reported internationally and in the 2004 study
dietary exposure to dioxins for the general Australian population is acceptably low
the Australian food supply is safe in relation to levels of dioxins

current risk management measures, which include maximum levels in the Australia New Zealand Food Standards Code, where appropriate, are effective in ensuring that dioxin levels remain as low as reasonably achievable.

The complete set of dioxin concentration and dietary exposure data for the 26th ATDS are publicly available in the report appendices on the FSANZ website at www.foodstandards.gov.au and searching '26th Australian Total Diet Study'. Regarding your query about emergency workers, states and territories are the first responders to any incident that occurs within their jurisdiction and have primary responsibility for the protection of life, property, and the environment within the bounds of their jurisdiction. This includes responsibility for ensuring their emergency services are trained to fulfil their emergency response roles and responsibilities.

The National Emergency Management Agency (NEMA) does not have responsibility in training state and territory emergency service personnel. NEMA may receive a request for assistance from the states and territories during crisis response and recovery, especially where a disaster or crisis exceeds their capacity to respond. NEMA works closely with jurisdictions and communities to better prepare for disasters and recover long-term and remains committed to working collaboratively to identify challenges and provide viable solutions.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Acting Minister for Health and Aged Care, Ms Wells
Medicare
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 18 May 2023 regarding Petition number EN4872—to improve access to Medicare for telehealth consultations with GPs.

The design of permanent Medicare Benefits Schedule (MBS) items for telehealth services was informed by the findings of the MBS Review Taskforce and other clinical experts. The requirement for a patient to have an established clinical relationship to be eligible for most common MBS telehealth services by GPs is aimed at promoting high-quality patient care. The available evidence suggests the best clinical outcomes from telehealth are achieved when it is part of a continuum of care, for patients' known medical conditions.

For GP telehealth services, an established clinical relationship requires telehealth services to be provided by the patient's usual practitioner; defined as a medical practitioner (other than a specialist or consultant physician) who has provided at least one face-to-face service to the patient in the past 12 months; or is located at a medical practice at which at least one face-to-face service to the patient was provided, or arranged by, in the past 12 months. The established relationship requirement is an ongoing requirement with respect to every telehealth consultation.

The requirement for a patient to have an established clinical relationship with a GP to access Medicare funded telehealth services with GPs has been in place since July 2020. This followed the rapid expansion of telehealth in response to COVID-19 and was designed and implemented in consultation with primary health care peak representatives.
For each telehealth consultation, the patient must meet the established clinical relationship requirements, unless one of the following exemptions applies.
The established relationship requirement does not apply to:
children under the age of 12 months
people who are homeless
patients receiving an urgent after-hours (unsociable hours) service
patients of medical practitioners at an Aboriginal Medical Service or an Aboriginal Community Controlled Health Service
people living in an area declared as a natural disaster area due by a state or territory Government
people isolating because of a COVID-related state or territory public health order, or in COVID-19 quarantine because of a state or territory public health order
people living in a state or territory local Government area which is currently declared as a natural disaster area
patients accessing specific MBS items for:
o blood borne viruses, sexual or reproductive health consultations
o pregnancy counselling services
o mental health services
o nicotine and smoking cessation counselling.
Temporary exemptions from the established relationship requirements are also in place, with the effect that patients with or suspected to have COVID-19 can receive timely care:
from 19 July 2022 until 31 December 2023, patients who are eligible for COVID-19 oral anti-viral medication and require a long telephone consult to be assessed medication suitability

from 14 October 2022 until 31 December 2023, patients that have tested COVID-19 positive within the last seven days, verified by either a laboratory test or COVID-19 rapid antigen self-test which has been approved for supply in Australia by the Therapeutic Goods Administration

from 1 January 2023 until 31 December 2023, a person who suspects they have COVID-19 and who meets the PBS criteria for COVID-19 antiviral therapy and requires a GP referral for a PCR test to verify diagnosis.

New patients of a practice and regular patients who have not attended the practice face to face in the preceding 12 months, must have a face-to-face attendance if they do not satisfy the above exemptions. Subsequent services may be provided by telehealth, if safe and clinically appropriate to do so.

Patients who are housebound due to chronic illness or disability are encouraged to discuss the possibility of a home visit with their GP to fulfill the annual face-to-face requirement. Higher Medicare fees and rebates are a longstanding provision for services provided outside of consultation rooms, recognising the additional effort of GPs who travel to provide care to their patients.

It is an Australian Government priority to maintain the highest standards of care for people and telehealth services cannot substitute for all in-person care. Regular face-to-face appointments remain important to ensure that patients, particularly those who have complex medical needs, are provided with comprehensive care including opportunities for physical observations.

I have asked the MBS Review Advisory Committee to monitor the use and impact of permanent telehealth arrangements, for both patients and practitioners and provide advice to Government in late 2023. This includes consideration of the established relationship requirement, existing exemptions and consideration of requests for additional exemptions for specific patient cohorts.

In regard to patients' concerns about attending GP clinics in person for fear of contracting COVID-19, the Government has released a 'National COVID-19 Health Management Plan for 2023 (National Plan) which is available at www.health.gov.au/sites/default/files/2022- 12/national-covid-19-health-management-plan-for-2023 0.pdf.

Informed by the likely 2023 Australian epidemiological outlook and advice from the Chief Medical Officer, Professor Paul Kelly, the National Plan outlines the Government measures to manage COVID-19 over the next 12 months.
Over 2023, Australia is expected to transition to managing COVID-19 in a similar way to other respiratory viruses, moving away from bespoke arrangements. The key objectives of the National Plan are:
minimising the level of severe COVID-19 and death
prioritising those at risk of severe illness, including through targeted supports
ensuring the health system as a whole has the capacity and capability to respond to future waves and variants
promoting uptake of COVID-19 vaccinations and treatments
slowing the spread of transmission, including through each individual's actions and engagement with protective measures.
In addition to the National Plan, in November 2022, the Government released a National COVID-19 Community Protection Framework, available at:

www.health.gov.au/resources/publications/national-covid-19-community-protection-framework?language=en outlining what public health measures states and territories might put in place to manage the COVID-19 pandemic. This includes strategies to address infection risk for individuals at high risk of serious infection.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Hospitals: Perinatal Bereavement Suites
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 17 May 2023 on behalf of the House of Representative's Standing Committee on Petitions regarding petition EN4873, which seeks a bereavement suite or room to be included in every hospital in Australia.

I acknowledge that each year in Australia, up to 110,000 families experience stillbirth or miscarriage. The death of a baby is a devastating and traumatic experience for parents, their families and support people, regardless of when the death occurs or the reason for the loss.

In Australia, maternity services are delivered through a mix of public and private services. The planning and delivery of Australian maternity services is predominantly undertaken by the states and territories through publicly funded care models, with the Australian Government providing national direction and supporting efforts to improve maternity care and outcomes.

The National Health Reform Agreement (NHRA), agreed between the Government and all states and territories, sets out the governance and funding arrangements for public hospital services in Australia, including maternity services. The NHRA recognises that state and territory governments are the system managers of their public hospital systems, responsible for both system wide planning and the day-to-day administration of their public hospitals.

In their system manger role, states and territories determine the policies and arrangements to ensure the respectful and patient focussed provision of birthing services in their public hospitals, including any dedicated bereavement suite or room for families who have suffered a stillbirth. The Government does not have the power to mandate that states and territories provide specific services or facilities in public hospitals. Additionally, the Government does not regulate or licence private hospitals in respect of maternity facilities. As such, the petitioners may also wish to contact their respective state or territory Health Ministers.

The Government is working closely with state and territory governments to improve the quality and safety of health services in health care setting across Australia, and to this end, providing funds for the Australian Commission on Safety and Quality in Health Care (Commission). The Commission aims to ensure that the health system is better informed, supported and organised to deliver safe and high-quality care through the development of standards such as the Clinical Care Standards.

Clinical Care Standards are nationally accepted standards of care for specific clinical conditions, for use in health services across Australia. The Stillbirth Clinical Care Standard describes the care that should be provided to women and also addresses bereavement care for parents who have experienced any form of perinatal loss.

According to the Stillbirth Clinical Care Standard, healthcare services should ensure policies, procedures and protocols are implemented to support clinicians in providing respectful, comprehensive and culturally safe bereavement care to families experiencing a perinatal loss. This includes caring for families in locations that are private, quiet, and separate from other mothers and newborn babies, whenever possible. Further information is available online at www.safetyandquality.gov.au.

In addition, the Government has invested a total of $44.5 million in measures to reduce stillbirths and support families affected by stillbirth under the National Stillbirth Action and Implementation Plan. Components of this funding include:

$4.2 million for Red Nose Australia's Hospital to Home Program, which offers targeted support services for families who experience stillbirth, including early support to assist in the transfer of bereaved families between hospital and support services

$5.1 million in grants for three organisations to develop and implement holistic and individualised bereavement care for women and families from higher-risk population groups who have experienced stillbirth or miscarriage, and education for the health professionals who support them.

The Government also led the development of the Woman-centred care: Strategic directions for Australian maternity services to provide national strategic directions to support Australia's high-quality maternity care system and enable improvements in line with contemporary practice, evidence, and international developments.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 18 May 2023 regarding petition EN4886 on the delisting of Fiasp(R) and Fiasp FlexTouch(R) from the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS).

From time to time, medicines are delisted from the PBS. This generally occurs at the request of the company responsible for the supply of the medicine in Australia (sponsor). If the sponsor requests to delist the only brand of an item listed on the PBS, a formal request and. a reason for delisting must be submitted to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC) for consideration.

The PBAC is an independent expert body which advises the Australian Government about the listing of medicines on the PBS and comprises of experts in the fields of medicine, health economics, social policy, health technology and pharmacology.

The Government relies on the advice of the PBAC when considering the removal of medicines from the PBS. It also cannot change the circumstances of a listing on the PBS unless the PBAC makes a recommendation in favour of doing so. When considering a medicine for proposed PBS delisting or listing the PBAC is required to give consideration to the effectiveness and cost of the medicine, including by comparing with that of alternative treatments.

Novo Nordisk Pharmaceuticals Pty Limited, the sponsor of the brands Fiasp and Fiasp FlexTouch, requested the delisting of these brands from the PBS from 1 April 2023 due to a commercial decision. The Summary of Changes is published on the PBS website at www.pbs.gov.au/publication/schedule/2023/04/2023-04-01-general-soc.pdf.

The PBAC considered the delisting of these brands and noted patients would be able to switch to other PBS-listed forms of insulin aspart. There are currently four forms of insulin aspart (supplied as five brands) subsidised through the PBS, which are set out in the table below:
Vial—100 units per ml, 10 ml (fast acting)
Fiasp
Vial—100 units per ml, 10 ml
NovoRapid
Pre-filled pen—100 units per ml, 3 ml, 5 (fast acting)
Fiasp FlexTouch
Cartridges—100 units per ml, 3 ml, 5
NovoRapid FlexPen
NovoRapid Penfill 3 ml

To assist patients in the transition to alternative formulations of insulin aspart, Fiasp and Fiasp FlexTouch are subject to a six month 'Supply Only' period on the PBS from 1 April 2023 to 30 September 2023.

During this period, patients will be able to continue to fill any of their prescriptions for Fiasp that were written before 1 April 2023 and these prescriptions will continue to be subsidised under the PBS.

The 'Supply Only' period will also provide longer time for consultations to occur between patients and their treating health professionals about obtaining new prescriptions for alternative insulin aspart products on the PBS, as listed in the table above. All aspects of patient care, including recommendations about appropriate treatments, are the responsibility of the treating medical professional.

It would be open to the sponsor of the medicine to make a further submission to the PBAC at any time to change the current listing of the medicine on the PBS. However, sponsors are private entities that make their own decisions regarding their products and cannot be compelled by the Government to continue to list a product on the PBS.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Broadband
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your letter of 17 May 2023 regarding Petition EN4892 which requests NBN upgrades for Smythesdale, Scarsdale and surrounding regional towns in Victoria.

Improving the quality, resilience and reliability of telecommunications services for regional Australians is one of the Government's top priorities. The Government is investing in the NBN to improve regional connectivity and deliver benefits to millions of Australians.

Residents in Smythesdale and Scarsdale are among the one million premises in regional and remote Australia that will have access to higher speeds on NBN fixed wireless services or greater data limits on Sky Muster services as a result of the Government providing $480 million towards an upgrade of the NBN fixed wireless network by the end of 2024.

All premises in the new, expanded fixed wireless coverage footprint will be able to access higher peak speed services of up to 100 megabits per second (Mbps) download with peak upload speeds of up to 20 Mbps. Around 85 per cent of fixed wireless premises will be able to access a service with peak download speeds of up to 250 Mbps and peak upload speeds of up to 20 Mbps. The upgrade is also expected to allow the fixed wireless network to achieve typical wholesale busy period download speeds of at least 50 Mbps (for consumers on broadband plans with higher advertised speeds than 50 Mbps).

The upgrade has also enabled NBN Co to launch the new Sky Muster Plus Premium plan that delivers 100 per cent unmetered data usage and faster burst speeds of up to 100 Mbps. This follows a successful trial with over 10,000 Sky Muster Plus customers to test the feasibility of the new product.

Sky Muster Plus Premium is the latest step in enhancing the NBN Sky Muster satellite network to keep pace with customer expectations and advancements in technology to deliver more capacity for satellite users, enhanced network performance and enhanced data allowances.

At present around 400,000 homes and small businesses are able to connect to the NBN via satellite but this number will drop as the fixed wireless upgrade progresses.
