By the end of the fixed wireless upgrade, around 300,000 premises across Australia will have access to the NBN via Sky Muster services. This reduction in numbers, will support NBN Co to provide enhanced consumer experience to those on Sky Muster services.

Furthermore, the Government has committed $656 million to the Better Connectivity Plan for Regional and Rural Australia which aims to further improve communications services in regional and rural communities, including through further rounds of the Regional Connectivity Program (RCP).
Applications are now being accepted for Round 3 of the RCP and are open until 11 August 2023.

As part of the application process, the Government has also launched an online project noticeboard to help regional communities like Smythesdale and Scarsdale, as well as local, state and territory governments and other interested parties to form partnerships with the telecommunications sector and to develop applications for funding. The noticeboard can be accessed on the department's website at www.infrastructure.gov.au/media-communications-arts/internet/regional-connectivity-program/register-your-project-proposal-rcp.

The petition also requests a mandate for internet service providers (ISPs) to support IPv6 services. While many ISPs in Australia support IPv6 services, many do not. The delivery of telecommunications services is highly competitive, which empowers consumers to choose service providers that support their needs. Consumers may wish to consider whether their provider complies with IPv6 when comparing available services. It is not current Government policy to mandate the use of IPv6 by ISPs.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Ms Rowland
Disability Support Pension
Dear Chair
Thank you for the notice of a petition referral (petition number EN4899) dated 17 May 2023, regarding the Disability Support Pension and the partner income test.

Australia's social security system is designed to provide a safety net for people who, for reasons such as age, disability, caring responsibilities or unemployment, are unable to fully support themselves. The Australian Government is committed to a welfare system that supports the most vulnerable, encourages those who are able to work or study, and is sustainable for future generations.

The social security income test uses the gross income of both partners, even if one of the partners does not receive a social security payment. This is based on the principle that couples are able to pool their resources for their mutual benefit. Couples generally share their expenses, such as various utilities including electricity, gas, internet and water. Accordingly, the income of each member of a couple is assessed for the purposes of the social security income test.

Taking into account the combined gross income and assets of both partners also ensures that partnered couples with similar (combined) levels of resources receive similar support from the social security system. If a partnered person's income support entitlements were based solely on their own income, this would result in unfair outcomes. For example, a couple where one person earned $80,000 and the other earned no income would receive more income support than another couple who both earned $40,000. In a needs-based social security system, this would not be equitable.

If a partnered person's income support entitlements were based solely on their own income, it would also create the situation where some couples could arrange their affairs so that only one member of a couple earns income—for example, income from investments—with the other member of the couple able to obtain a higher level of support from the social security system than would otherwise be the case.

Services Australia (Centrelink) has social workers who can assist people who are struggling financially. They can provide information or a referral to financial counselling services which are free. The Department of Social Services also provides funding to community organisations to deliver free, voluntary and confidential financial counselling services. Under these services, financial counsellors work with people in financial difficulty to address their financial problems, manage debt and make informed choices about their money in the future.
I appreciate you bringing this matter to my attention and hope the above information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Social Services, Ms Rishworth
Defence Personnel
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence of 23 May 2023 regarding petition number EN4903 regarding mandatory military service for school leavers.

The Government does not believe that there is a need for a mandatory conscription scheme for school leavers at this time. Defence' s primary role is protecting and advancing Australia's strategic interests. The Government believes that maintaining a well-trained and highly professional ADF is the most effective way of delivering on Australia's Defence requirements.

The nature of military service in the current environment is such that our service personnel require substantial training to enable them to operate in complex and varied situations. To train a conscript force to a competent and safe level would require significant resources and take those highly trained and experienced personnel away from their primary role of delivering Defence capability to the nation.

Notwithstanding the above, the Government does believe Australia's youth can benefit from close association with the ADF. There are a number of Defence initiatives to support youth engagement including the Cadets, the Young Endeavour Youth Scheme, the Defence Work Experience Program and the Gap Year program. More information is available at www.defenceyouth.gov.au.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours faithfully,
from the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Mr Keogh
General Practitioners
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 17 May 2023 regarding petition EN4906—to increase the Medicare rebate and financial support to GP practices.
The 2023-24 Budget provided a historic $6.1billion investment in Medicare to lay the foundations for significant reform to general practice and primary care for all Australians.

It delivers critical funding to meet urgent healthcare needs of today, while starting reforms to build a stronger Medicare for future generations. The Budget responds to the recommendations of the Strengthening Medicare Taskforce and takes the key steps needed to address the many pressing challenges in Australia's healthcare system. Key measures which will strengthen Medicare include:
$3.5 billion investment to triple bulk billing incentives to support free GP consultations for children, the elderly and other Commonwealth concession card holders
$1.5 billion investment in an indexation boost to Medicare rebates
$951 million to improve digital health technologies
$236.5 million for the new MyMedicare system that will enable health teams to provide more tailored care
$1.6 billion saving to patients by enabling patients to buy two months' worth of medicine in a single prescription
$47.8 million for a chronic wound consumable scheme for patients with diabetes

a range of additional measures to build a bigger health and aged care workforce that is skilled, diverse, motivated, well-distributed and sustainable, and has all clinicians working to the full extent of their skills and training.
Further information on these changes can be found in the Building a Stronger Medicare Budget fact sheet at www.health.gov.au/resources/publications/building-a-stronger-medicare-budget- 2023-24.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Parenting Payment
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence dated 17 May 2023, concerning petition EN4919 that seeks the Australian Government to increase Parenting Payment (Single).
The Government welcomes feedback from the community, and I acknowledge the concerns raised in the petition about the financial circumstances of single parents on income support.

The Government recognises the important role that parents play as carers of children in Australia. The Government is committed to building a social security system that provides a strong safety net to support and supports single parents, women and people in Australia who rely on income support.

In the 2023-24 Budget, the Government announced a $1.9 billion expansion of Parenting Payment (Single) by raising the youngest dependent child age limit from 8 to 14 years. Under this measure, eligible single principal carers will no longer transfer to JobSeeker Payment when their youngest child turns 8 and will continue to receive support through Parenting Payment (Single) until their youngest dependent child turns 14. By 14 years of age, children have typically settled into high school and need less parental supervision, and single parents are in a much stronger position to take on paid work.

This measure will enable eligible single parents to continue to receive the higher level of support provided by Parenting Payment (Single), with a current base rate of $922.10 per fortnight, until their youngest child turns 14. With these changes, eligible single parents currently on JobSeeker Payment will receive an increase to payments of $176.90 per fortnight.
More than 90 per cent of parents who will benefit from this change are single mothers.

Recipients transferring from JobSeeker Payment who earn income will also benefit from the more generous income testing arrangements associated with Parenting Payment (Single). They will continue to receive the same level of support from Family Tax Benefit (Part A and Part B) and other applicable supplements such as Rent Assistance, Pharmaceutical Allowance and Telephone Allowance.

These changes will commence from 20 September 2023, subject to the passage of legislation. This timing aligns with the next round of legislated indexation changes for Parenting Payment. This means recipients will receive the increases announced through the Budget and any increase resulting from indexation, at the same time.
I trust the information provided will be of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Social Services, Ms Rishworth

subdebateinfo.title: International Relations: Australia and the United States of America

p.span: International Relations: Australia and the United States of America
Dear Chair
Thank you for your letter conveying Petition EN4926.

The Albanese Government is deploying all elements of national power to make Australia more stable, confident and secure at home, and more influential in the world. Australia exercises our own agency and makes decisions in our own interests.

The Alliance between Australia and the United States has never been more important given our current strategic environment. The United States has been an indispensable partner whose contributions to the strategic balance in our region has guaranteed a long, uninterrupted period of stability and prosperity. As our region has changed, so too has our Alliance with the United States. For example, we are building cooperation across economic development, climate change, health and disaster management. We recognise that Australia's security and prosperity is best served by a strategic equilibrium in our region, to which the United States plays a crucial balancing role.

The Australian Government is committed to defend and advance the principles enshrined in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, both at home and abroad. All countries have room for improvement in their human rights situations, and the United States is no exception. Australia has regular engagement with the United States on human rights. The United States has a diverse and robust polity with checks and balances, and varied pathways to ensure that fundamental rights and freedoms are guaranteed. The 2020 Universal Period Review of the United States, undertaken by the Human Rights Council every five years, recognised longstanding US leadership in shaping and protecting international human rights. Australia has also welcomed President Biden's very clear support for sexual and reproductive health and rights, as demonstrated by his Executive Orders to safeguard access to these health services.
Our Government will continue to ensure that Australia's alliances and partnerships serve our national interest and support the peace, stability and prosperity of the Indo-Pacific.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong
Ukraine
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your email sharing a petition calling for Australia to work with other countries to establish a ceasefire and peace talks relating to Russia's war in Ukraine.

Australia condemns Russia's illegal and immoral invasion of Ukraine. Russia's invasion renders stark Australia's commitment to a world in which no country dominates and no country is dominated. It is a gross violation of international law, including the Charter of the United Nations. Australia seeks a world that is peaceful and predictable, that is governed by accepted rules and norms, and where all countries can cooperate, trade and thrive.

Australia supports President Zelenskyy's 10 Point Peace Formula, which articulates Ukraine's terms for a just and lasting peace. Ukraine has made clear that the only way to achieve peace is to restore Ukraine's territorial integrity and hold Russia to account for its war of aggression. We continue to work with partners to empower Ukraine to resolve this conflict on its own terms. This objective underpins both our support for Ukraine and our efforts to impose costs on Russia.

Australia unequivocally supports Ukraine's sovereignty, territorial integrity and right to self- determination. Through the Quad Leaders' Joint Statement in May, Prime Minister Albanese affirmed that Australia stands for "adherence to international law, peaceful resolution of dispute and respect for principles of the UN Charter". The Prime Minister earlier reiterated the need for "an immediate cessation of hostilities and a peaceful resolution to the conflict" in the Joint Statement of the 1st Australia-India Annual Summit held in March.

Australia's calls for peace and respect for international law are reflected in our actions. Australia co-sponsored and voted in favour of the resolution 'Principles for a comprehensive, just and lasting peace in Ukraine' at the United Nations General Assembly on 23 February 2023. Through this resolution, the General Assembly reaffirmed its commitment to Ukraine's sovereignty and territorial integrity, underscored the need to reach a lasting peace in Ukraine as soon as possible and called on UN member states to redouble diplomatic efforts to achieve this. It also called on Russia to completely and unconditionally withdraw its military forces from Ukraine and to cease hostilities.

The Government is committed to holding Russia to account for its illegal and unprovoked invasion of Ukraine; an invasion that cannot be minimised and cannot be normalised. We are working closely with Five Eyes, G7 and other partners to impose significant economic and political costs on Russia and those supporting its invasion. The Government continues to expand Australia's comprehensive suite of sanctions and trade measures against Russia: denying Russia access to our markets and ensuring Australia does not inadvertently fund Russia's war machine. We have imposed more than 1,100 targeted financial sanctions in response to Russia's full-scale invasion. We have also joined a core group of partners to file an intervention at the International Court of Justice in support of Ukraine's case against Russia to ensure Russia's leadership is held accountable.
In addition to our diplomatic efforts and defence assistance for Ukraine, Australia is proud to have provided $75 million in humanitarian aid to help meet the needs of the Ukrainian people.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong(Petition No. EN4928)
Telecommunications
Dear Chair
Thank you for your email of 17 May 2023 regarding Petition EN4939 requesting that telecommunications companies be prevented from imposing direct debit only payment options on customers.

The Australian Government will do what is necessary to ensure that telecommunications services enrich the lives of all Australians rather than cause them inconvenience, frustration, or detriment. I am considering the existing telecommunications consumer protections framework to determine whether it remains fit for purpose.

I am aware of concerns being raised about the increasing preference of telecommunications providers for direct debit payment and limiting payment options. I thank the petitioners for raising this matter and note it has also been raised by the Australian Communications and Media Authority (ACMA) and the Australian Communications Consumer Action Network. I am looking at the issue closely.

By way of background, I note that telecommunications-specific consumer protections are contained in various legislation, industry standards and service provider determinations. They are also contained in industry codes, such as the Telecommunications Consumer Protections Code (TCP Code), which is designed to protect consumer rights and to make clear the obligations of telephone and internet service providers.

The TCP Code provides safeguards on issues such as sales and customer service, contracts, billing, credit and debt management and changing suppliers. The TCP Code requires, among other things, telecommunications providers to offer at least one free bill payment method. However, I note the ACMA has not formed the view that direct debit payment options breach existing rules. Further information is available on the website of the ACMA at: www.acma.gov.au/telecommunications-consumer-protection-code.

The TCP Code was developed by the telecommunications industry body, Communications Alliance, in consultation with stakeholders. It was then registered by the ACMA. The current version of the code is required to be reviewed in 2024, however, the review process has already commenced. You can find further information on the website of Communications Alliance at www.commsalliance.com.au/Documents/TCP-Code-Review-2024.

I recently held a consumer roundtable with key stakeholders to discuss the retail-level consumer protection framework. Participants included consumer and industry representatives, the Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman and the ACMA. I am considering advice provided at the Roundtable including calls for greater use of directly enforceable regulation, in conjunction with (or instead of) aspects of the TCP Code.

I will make any further announcements in relation to the consumer safeguards framework in due course. I refer the petitioners to my Department's website where I will publish any relevant announcements, there is also a subscription service to receive notifications, at www.minister.infrastructure.gov.au/rowland/media-release.
Thank you for bringing the petitioners' concerns to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Ms Rowland
Pakistan
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for passing on a petition regarding the political and human rights situation in Pakistan.

The Australian Government calls on all parties in Pakistan to uphold democracy and the rule of law, while respecting and promoting human rights for all. This includes holding free and fair elections in line with Pakistan's constitution. We regularly engage with all sides of politics including through our High Commissioner in Pakistan. As well as meeting government ministers, the High Commissioner has met senior members of Pakistan Tehreek-e-lnsaf, including Mr Khan in late May.

The Australian Government is a steadfast advocate for human rights globally. We have longstanding concerns about the situation in Pakistan and regularly make representations to the Pakistan Government, urging it to ensure freedom of expression and of association, to foster tolerance, and to strengthen civil society and its institutions. We continue to raise our concerns in multilateral fora, including the United Nations Human Rights Council.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong(Petition No. EN4942)
Taylor, Leading Seaman Ronald (Buck)
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 17 May 2023 on behalf of the Standing Committee on Petitions concerning Petition EN4948—Victoria Cross Medal awarded to Leading Seaman Ronald Taylor 20863 for his actions serving in HMAS Yarra on 4 March 1942.

Leading Seaman Taylor's actions were reviewed during the Defence Honours and Awards Appeals Tribunal (the Tribunal) Inquiry into 'Unresolved Recognition for Past Acts of Naval and Military Gallantry and Valour'. A copy of the 2013 Inquiry report is available at: https://defence-honours-tribunal.gov.au/wp-content/uploads/2019/Valour-lnquiry-Report.pdf

Chapter 24 of the Inquiry Report details the Tribunal's consideration of recognition for Leading Seaman Taylor. The Tribunal found Leading Seaman Taylor's case was not handled properly at the time. The Tribunal conducted merit reviews into his actions on S February and 4 March 1942, and concluded 'that there was insufficient evidence to recommend the award of an individual gallantry honour to Taylor for his actions'.

The Tribunal recommended Leading Seaman Taylor, along with the other crew members of HMAS Yarra, be recognised as a collective ship's company with a Unit Citation for Gallantry. On 2 March 2014 the Governor-General awarded HMAS Yarra (II) a Unit Citation for Gallantry for acts of extraordinary gallantry in action off Singapore on 5 February 1942 and in the Indian Ocean on 4 March 1942.

I acknowledge the petitioners' interest and advocacy for Leading Seaman Taylor. However, noting the conclusions and recommendations of the Tribunal Inquiry there are no plans to review recognition for Leading Seaman Taylor.

If the petitioners have new evidence or information that was not available to the Tribunal Inquiry and may support a case for another merit review of the actions of Leading Seaman Taylor, they may contact Defence Honours and Awards via email at dha.policy@defence.gov.au for guidance on preparing an application for review.
Thank you for bringing this matter to my attention. I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Defence, Mr Marles
Pakistan
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for passing on a petition regarding the political and human rights situation in Pakistan.

The Australian Government calls on all parties in Pakistan to uphold democracy and the rule of law, while respecting and promoting human rights for all. This includes holding free and fair elections in line with Pakistan's constitution. We regularly engage with all sides of politics including through our High Commissioner in Pakistan. As well as meeting government ministers, the High Commissioner has met senior members of Pakistan Tehreek-e-lnsaf, including Mr lmran Khan in late May.

The Australian Government is a steadfast advocate for human rights globally. We have longstanding concerns about the situation in Pakistan and regularly make representations to the Pakistan Government, urging it to ensure freedom of expression and of association, to foster tolerance, and to strengthen civil society and its institutions. We continue to raise our concerns in multilateral fora, including the United Nations Human Rights Council.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong (Petition No. EN4954)
Pensions and Benefits
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence dated 17 May 2023, concerning petition EN4958 that seeks the Australian Government to cease the biannual indexation of unemployment payments.

The social security system is a safety net that delivers on the Government's commitment to support vulnerable people and ensure no one is left behind. Australia's social security system is a non-contributory system designed to support the basic living standards of all Australians, and increase their social and economic participation. It is a means-tested, residence based system, designed to provide income support to people who, for reasons such as age, unemployment or ill health, are unable to support themselves.

Income support payments, including the JobSeeker Payment, are designed to support people in Australia who are unable to support themselves whilst they look for a job or have a temporary injury or incapacity. Generally, most recipients of unemployment payments are also required to meet mutual obligation requirements. Mutual obligations policy is carefully considered by the Government in order to help people connect to employment and become job ready through engaging with employment services, job searching and participating in other activities.

The Government recognises that living on income support payments is challenging, and it is important rates of payments keep up with the cost of living. To address the effects of inflation on cost of living for those on a payment, income support payments such as JobSeeker Payment are increased each year in March and September in line with the Consumer Price Index.

Indexation of income support payments is a longstanding practice and is set out in legislation in the Social Security Act 1991. Payment indexation helps to ensure that Australians on some of the lowest incomes are able to continue to afford essential goods and services, by maintaining the real value of payments.

People who depend on income support for long periods rather than paid work face increased risks of financial hardship and exclusion from the workforce. The Government believes that every person should have the opportunity to find suitable employment and experience the benefits of being in a job, rather than relying on income support.

The income and assets tests aim to ensure that income support is directed to those most in need with support reducing as the capacity of recipients to provide for themselves increases. The income test for income support payments includes income test free areas and proportional income test withdrawal rates. This gradual reduction of income support as a person earns more means that recipients are better off if they or their partner earn additional income, rather than relying solely on income support.
I appreciate you bringing this matter to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Social Services, Ms Rishworth
Sri Lanka
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your email of 18 May 2023 regarding petition number EN4961, presented in the House on 9 May 2023.

The Australian Government continues to monitor the delay in local government elections in Sri Lanka. Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade officials have discussed this matter with the Sri Lankan Government through our High Commission in Colombo and, most recently, in Canberra.

Since the start of the economic crisis, Australia's $75 million of humanitarian and development assistance has been targeted to meet immediate needs, including food security, health and nutrition, as well as building towards inclusive economic recovery. Our humanitarian and development assistance is delivered through partners, including UN agencies and other non-government organisations.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong
Health Care: Family Planning
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 17 May 2023 on behalf of the House of Representative's Standing Committee on Petitions regarding petition EN4969, seeking to make sterilisation accessible to those who want it.

Supporting, protecting and promoting the health and wellbeing of all Australian women and girls is a key priority for the Australian Government. The health of Australian women and girls is critical to their overall wellbeing and ability to participate in society. Women's health impacts not only individuals but also their families and communities.

Under the Medicare Benefits Schedule (MBS), there are currently items to support access to permanent contraception surgical procedures, which may include sterilisation procedures or procedures that remove reproductive organs such as hysterectomy (uterus) or oophorectomy (ovary). These procedures can only be provided in-hospital. There is also an MBS item available for a unilateral or bilateral vasotomy or vasectomy that can be provided in or out of hospital.

For all medical services funded through Medicare, including permanent sterilisation, it is the responsibility of the practitioner providing the service to ensure that the service is clinically relevant and that all of the requirements of the relevant MBS item, as detailed in the item descriptor and associated explanatory notes, have been met. A medical service is considered clinically relevant if it is generally accepted in the medical profession as necessary for the appropriate treatment of the patient.

Australia's National Women's Health Strategy 2020-2030 (Strategy) outlines a national approach to improving health outcomes for all women and girls, particularly those at greatest risk of poor health, and aims to reduce inequities in health outcomes. The. Strategy proposes action in five priority areas including maternal, sexual, and reproductive health.

The Government has established the National Women's Health Advisory Council (Council) to provide strategic advice and recommendations directly to Government to improve health outcomes for Australian women and girls. The Council membership is comprised of a mix of peak stakeholder organisations, consumer groups, academics, and medical and professional bodies to contribute the breadth of knowledge, expertise, and experiences necessary to inform all aspects of women's health.

The Senate Community Affairs References Committee recently released its report from the Inquiry into universal access to reproductive healthcare titled 'Ending the postcode lottery: Addressing barriers to sexual, maternity and reproductive healthcare in Australia' (the Report). The Inquiry aimed to address barriers to achieving priorities under the National Women's Health Strategy with reference to sexual and reproductive health information, treatment and services that offer options to women to empower choice and control in decision making about their bodies.
The Government is currently considering the recommendations of the Report, including enhancing access to and affordability of contraceptives, and will provide a response.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Eating Disorders
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 31 May 2023 regarding petition number EN4972—increase resources and funding for eating disorders.

I acknowledge the substantial impact eating disorders can take on a person's mental, physical, and psychological wellbeing, as well as for their family and carers. The Australian Government is aware of the gaps within the eating disorder system of care and is committed to improving eating disorder services and treatment options to improve patient outcomes and relieve the strain on hospitals.

I recognise the national significance of investing in ensuring all Australians can access affordable and appropriate supports and services for eating disorders. The Government has committed $271 million to eating disorder initiatives between 2018-19 and 2025-26 to address the gaps within the system of care and to improve eating disorder treatment and services nationally. The Government has committed to the following eating disorder initiatives:

Increasing the accessibility and affordability of eating disorder treatments in the community setting through specific Medicare Benefits Schedule (MBS) items for eating disorders, enabling up to 40 psychology and 20 dietetic treatment sessions per year for those eligible for an Eating Disorder Treatment and Management Plan ($110.7 million).
A Rational coordination role for the National Eating Disorder Collaboration (NEDC) to build an effective, equitable and accessible system of care for all Australians ($6.9 million).
Operation of Butterfly Foundation's National Helpline, ED Hope. The Helpline provides supports for those concerned about eating disorders or body image issues and their loved ones ($9.5 million).

Supporting the Butterfly Foundation's Body Bright Program, which provides curriculum resources and education to primary school teachers and parents to promote healthy attitudes and behaviours towards the body, food, and physical exercise ($0.65 million).

Developing the Eating Disorder Credential, which allows consumers to identify appropriately trained and experienced clinicians to seek eating disorders treatment from (connect-ed—ANZAED Eating Disorder Credential) ($3.26 million).
Upskilling staff at Head to Health and headspace Centres, to enhance their capacity to identify and treat eating disorders ($1.9 million).

Establishing the Australian Eating Disorder Research & Translation Centre to progress key eating disorder research priorities relating to prevention, early identification and intervention ($13 million).
Translation of eating disorder evidence into clinical practice by the Inside Out Institute ($4 million).
Supporting Eating Disorders Families Australia's Strive program, to provide education, learning and peer support to parents, carers, and families of people with eating disorders ($0.45 million).

Launching a series of coordinated initiatives under the Embrace Kids Australia brand aimed at improving the body image of young people across Australia and preventing the prevalence of eating disorders ($6.2 million).

The Government has also provided $63 million to establish seven community-based residential eating disorder treatment centres through the Community Health and Hospitals Program. Wandi Nerida is a private facility on the Sunshine Coast operated by the Butterfly Foundation and this centre is operational. The Government is providing $8.5 million to Wandi Nerida for capital works, service establishment and delivery. The other six centres are being delivered in partnership with state and territory governments. The majority of the centres will be operational from mid to late 2024.

The NEDC is currently undertaking an activity to map eating disorders content in tertiary curricula for health professionals. This project will identify potential pathways for change in curricula to better equip a range of health professionals to respond to eating disorders. This will enable future health professionals to detect eating disorders early and support patients to access evidence-based treatment options.

On 29 May 2023, I announced the outcomes of the $20 million Community-Based Eating Disorder Supports grant opportunity, which addresses existing gaps in the system of care and identifies specialised treatment services to be delivered in the community setting, on a national scale. This grant opportunity will fund seven initiatives, including:

The University of Sydney— eClinic
. The eClinic will provide national access to digital evidence-based e-therapies either by self- or clinician-referral.

The NEDC— Right Care Right Place
.The NEDC will work with four Primary Health Networks to commission Eating Disorder Care Coordinators in their regions.

Eating Disorders Queensland— Brief Intervention Therapy for Eating Disorders (bITE)
. bITE will provide evidence-based interventions and support elements to provide clients with a guided journey towards recovery.

The University of Sydney— Digital GP Hub
.The Digital GP Hub will support GPs to provide evidence-based screening, assessment, treatment, and management to people with eating disorders.

headspace National Youth Mental Health Foundation—Embedding eating disorder treatment in headspace centres
. This program will deliver training and support activities to ensure headspace clinicians are able to identify and competently treat someone with an eating disorder and also identify those requiring more intensive support.

Eating Disorders Families Australia—Fill the Gap
.Fill the Gap will provide access to specifically designed supports for carers of those with eating disorders.

Butterfly Foundation— Virtual Intensive Outpatient Program (v-IOP)
.
v-IOP will provide stepped-down support for people with an eating disorder discharged from hospitals and residential centres. The program will incorporate group therapy, meal support programs, and lived experience focussed groups for participants over 16 years.

The Department of Health and Aged Care has also commissioned the La Trobe University to conduct an evaluation of the Eating Disorder MBS items ($1.97 million). The evaluation will aim to determine whether the items are operating as intended for patients and their families, clinicians, and the Government. The evaluation will inform the Government and key stakeholders how the Eating Disorder MBS items are working to achieve their aims and objectives.

Please be advised, the Government is also actively working with NEDC to deliver a National Eating Disorders Strategy. The Strategy will contribute to the development and implementation of a nationally consistent, evidence-based system of care for the prevention and treatment of eating disorders throughout Australia. This Strategy is due to be launched in August 2023.

The Government recognises the growing impact of eating disorders and the need to enhance access to appropriate services and supports through a coordinated system of care. We are working in collaboration with state and territory governments and sector stakeholders to fill the gaps within the stepped system of care. The significant investments outlined above represent the Government's commitment to providing access to more affordable and appropriate eating disorder services and treatment. I recognise there is more work to do to ensure all Australians experience positive outcomes in their care journey.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Voluntary Assisted Dying
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 22 May 2023 regarding the petition to ban euthanasia in Australia (EN4980). I am responding as the Acting Minister for Health and Aged Care.

Voluntary assisted dying (VAD), sometimes referred to as euthanasia, is a very sensitive and complex issue, and I appreciate that members of the community have a range of views about this topic. The underlying principle of the Australian Government's investment in health services is quality of life, and this includes end-of-life care and supporting people to die with dignity, compassion and minimal pain.

Under Australia's federal system of government, the Commonwealth, states and territories have different areas of responsibility. State and territory governments are responsible for laws pertaining to voluntary assisted dying and euthanasia. The Government respects states and territories' rights to legislate for their own jurisdictions in a way that protects people's safety and dignity, and safeguards against unintended consequences.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Acting Minister for Health and Aged Care, Ms Wells
Education
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 22 May 2023 regarding petition EN4982 received by the Standing Committee on Petitions in the House of Representatives. Thank you for bringing this petition on the duration of bachelor degrees to my attention.

This issue relates to the Australian Qualifications Framework (AQF), the national policy that incorporates the qualifications from each education and training sector into a single comprehensive national qualifications framework.

Each qualification type in the AQF has a volume of learning specified. Volume of learning is the typical duration that is required for a student to achieve the learning outcomes for that qualification type. For example, the volume of learning of a Bachelor Degree is typically 3 to 4 years, while the volume of learning of a Certificate II is typically 6 months to 1 year, A typical year of full time study is considered to be around 1,200 hours. For more information, access www.aqf.edu.au/publication/volume-learning-v2-20l4.

The volume of learning allocated to a course of study should include all teaching, learning and assessment activities required to achieve the learning outcomes. These activities may include some or all of the following: guided learning (such as classes, lectures, tutorials, on-line study or self-paced study guides), individual study, research, learning activities in the workplace and assessment activities. Therefore, whilst a Bachelor Degree may only require 15 hours of classes per week (as stated in the petition), this is only a fraction of the total learning required in order to successfully complete the qualification.

In relation to the petition's comment that "Tradies should be taught by teachers not other tradies", I note that the Registered Training Organisation Standards require training and assessment to be delivered by persons who have the training and assessment credentials specified in the Standards. All trainers and assessors must also undertake professional development and hold vocational competencies at least to the level being delivered and assessed, current industry skills directly relevant to the training and assessment being provided, and current knowledge and skills in vocational training and learning that informs their training and assessment.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Education, Mr Clare

subdebateinfo.title: Universities: Nursing and Midwifery Training Placements

p.span: Universities: Nursing and Midwifery Training Placements
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 22 May 2023 to the Minister for Health and Aged Care, the Hon Mark Butler MP, regarding Petition EN4985 discussing financial support for current nursing and midwifery students while on clinical placements. I am responding as the Acting Minister for Health and Aged Care.

The Australian Government recognises the valuable contribution of the health professions in the community and is committed to making sure the highly qualified and skilled practitioner workforce is available to those who need it.

Student clinical placements are intended to provide the opportunity to apply the theory and skills learned in a professional workplace. Students completing placements are not considered to be employees and therefore are not remunerated under the Fair Work Act 2009.

Where a student's contract with the host business or organisation entitles them to receive money for the work they perform, the placement will likely turn into an employment relationship. You can find more information on this topic on the Fair Work Australia website at www.fairwork.gov.au and searching 'student placements'.

The Commonwealth Chief Nursing and Midwifery Officer meets with jurisdictional counterparts regularly to discuss the nursing and midwifery workforce. From these discussions, Victoria, Queensland, and Tasmania have established paid student nursing positions within their public health services.

In some other jurisdictions, nursing students can work as Assistants in Nursing (or however named) once they have completed 12 months of their degree program. In addition, many registered and enrolled nursing students work as personal care or support workers in the aged and disability care sectors while completing their degrees in nursing.

You may wish to contact your relevant jurisdiction to discuss their programs for nursing students. Contact details for each jurisdiction can be found on the Department of Health and Aged Care's website at www.health.gov.au by searching 'Local state and territory health departments'.

You may be interested to know that the Government is investing in a significant incentive for eligible doctors and nurse practitioners to live and practice in rural, remote or very remote areas of Australia by way of introducing the Higher Education Loan Program (HELP) Debt Reduction initiative.

This initiative aims to increase the number of doctors and nurse practitioners living and working in rural, remote or very remote areas of Australia by reducing outstanding HELP debt for those who meet the eligibility criteria and obligation requirements of the program.

Eligible doctors and nurse practitioners will be encouraged to live and work in rural, remote or very remote areas of Australia, with an offer from the Government to reduce their outstanding HELP debt, provided they meet the eligibility criteria and their obligations to complete the required amount of eligible work.
More information on this initiative can also be found on the department's website and searching 'HELP for rural doctors and nurse practitioners'.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Acting Minister for Health and Aged Care, Ms Wells
Cystic Fibrosis
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 22 May 2023 regarding petition number EN4994 requesting the listing of Trikafta(R) (elexacaftor/tezacaftor/ivacaftor and ivacaftor) on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) for the treatment of cystic fibrosis in patients aged six to 11 years.

As you may be aware, Trikafta was first listed on the PBS from 1 April 2022 for patients with cystic fibrosis aged 12 years and older, who have at least one F508del mutation in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) gene.

I was pleased to recently announce the expanded listing of Trikafta on the PBS from 1 May 2023. This expanded listing provides subsidised access for patients with cystic fibrosis aged six to 11 years, who have at least one FS08del mutation in the CFTR gene.
This listing is expected to benefit over 500 children a year. Without PBS subsidy, this treatment could cost more than $250,000 per year.
From 1 May 2023, families of eligible children pay a maximum of $30 per script, or $7.30 with a concession card.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
COVID-19: Response
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 22 May 2023 regarding petition number EN5000 calling for a Commonwealth Royal Commission into the COVID-19 pandemic response in Australia.

Australia has well established arrangements in place to respond quickly and effectively to a range of health emergencies. These arrangements are set out in health sector emergency management plans, which are designed to integrate with broader national emergency plans, particularly the Australian Government Crisis Management Framework.

Australia has world-class public health systems, and we are well-prepared to respond to communicable disease challenges. Australia works closely with the World Health Organization to ensure that it aligns with One Health activities across the suite of pandemic prevention, preparedness and response as part of its obligations under the International Health Regulations.

The Government's response to the COVID-19 pandemic continues to be informed by leading experts, including the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee (AHPPC) and the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation. Comprised of all state and territory Chief Health Officers and chaired by the Australian Chief Medical Officer, the AHPPC works with state and territory health departments to develop and adopt national health protection policies, guidelines, standards and seek alignment of plans.

On 30 June 2022, the Government commissioned an independent review of Australia's COVID-19 vaccine and treatment procurements. In September 2022 the review, led by Professor Jane Halton AO, handed down eight recommendations. The Government responded to the review in February 2023, accepting seven of the eight recommendations in full. The remaining recommendation, relating to the National Medical Stockpile, was partially accepted noting it was largely outside the terms of reference for the review.

The Prime Minister, the Hon Anthony Albanese MP, has indicated the Government will undertake, at an appropriate future time, an inquiry into Australia's COVID-19 response that will examine the impact of the pandemic and the respective actions of governments.

I also note all states and territories, except the Northern Territory, have conducted, or are in the process of conducting, parliamentary inquiries into their COVID-19 responses. The timing of any national inquiry must be well considered, noting Australia is still experiencing COVID-19, with heightened risk during winter months.

The Government is establishing an Australian Centre for Disease Control (ACDC) which will enhance Australia's ongoing response and preparedness for current and emerging public health emergencies. Once established, the ACDC will help ensure ongoing pandemic preparedness, lead the federal response to future disease outbreaks, and work to prevent both non-communicable (chronic) and communicable (infectious) diseases. A staged rollout of the CDC is planned to commence in early 2024.

Additional information on the establishment of the ACDC, including a summary of consultation feedback, is available on the Department of Health and Aged Care's website at www.health.gov.au/our-work/Australian-CDC.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Gender and Sexual Orientation
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 22 May 2023 regarding Petition EN5014—Remove testicles to be recognised as a woman in law.

The Australian Government believes all people are entitled to respect, dignity and the opportunity to participate in society regardless of their personal attributes. It recognises to enjoy civil and political rights on an equal basis with others, people need to be able to do so free from discrimination.

Commonwealth anti-discrimination laws make discrimination on the grounds of gender identity unlawful in a wide range of areas, including education, employment and the provision of goods, services and facilities.

The 'Australian Government Guidelines on the Recognition of Sex and Gender' (Guidelines) standardise the evidence required for a person to change their sex or gender in personal records. Under the Guidelines, sex reassignment surgery and/or hormone therapy are not prerequisites for the recognition of a change of gender. The Guidelines apply to all Commonwealth departments and agencies. Marriage, passports and records held through agencies such as Medicare and Centrelink are matters for the Commonwealth, whereas birth certificates and gender recognition certificates are within the jurisdiction of states and territories.

The Australian Government does not adopt a single definition to define a person's gender. Consideration is given to chromosomal makeup, gender assigned at birth, and gender with which a person identifies. Health policies and access to health programs are based on clinical evidence and clinical need for all Australians, regardless of gender identity, biological characteristics, or genetic variations.
All Government programs are designed to be inclusive and to provide better health and wellbeing for all Australians.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Human Rights: China
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence regarding petition number EN5016, presented in the House of Representatives on 22 May 2023, advocating for the imposition of sanctions and entry bans on Chinese individuals involved in perpetrating human rights violations and abuses in China.

The Australia Government has grave concerns about human rights in China: including human rights violations in Xinjiang; reports of the erosion of educational, religious, linguistic and cultural rights in Tibet; the persecution of individuals and groups on the basis of religion or belief; and the continuing erosion of rights and freedoms in Hong Kong.

The Government has been clear and consistent in raising these concerns, publicly and privately, directly with China and in multilateral forums. I have raised human rights concerns in all of my engagements with my Chinese counterparts. On 1 March, Assistant Foreign Minister Watts delivered a statement at the UN Human Rights Council (HRC), expressing Australia's concerns about human rights in China, including in Xinjiang and Tibet. Australia has joined all eight joint statements at the HRC and UN General Assembly about human rights in China—including Xinjiang, Tibet and Hong Kong- and regularly raises these concerns through national statements at the HRC.

The Australian Government employs every strategy at its disposal towards upholding human rights, consistent with our values and interests. Consistent with longstanding practice, we will not speculate on sanctions. Sanctions are only one tool available to government, and will rarely be our first choice in responding to human rights situations of concern. We will continue to convey our grave concerns about the human rights situation in China, and advocate directly with the Chinese Government, including at the highest level.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong
Age Pension
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your email dated 22 May 2023, concerning petition EN5020 to the House of Representatives, which relates to the residency requirements for the Age Pension.

I acknowledge the request in petition EN5020 for the inclusion of a discretionary power in relevant legislation enabling me, as Minister for Social Services, to make exceptions to Age Pension claim rules, where an individual is overseas due to extenuating circumstances.

Australia has a non-contributory, residence-based system. Under longstanding legislation, to claim an Australian social security payment, such as the Age Pension, a person must be both residing in Australia and physically present in Australia at the time of claim. Payment is also subject to other eligibility criteria, such as age requirements and income and assets tests.

The only exception to these rules is for former Australian residents living in a country that has a social security agreement with Australia. Australia currently has social security agreements with 31 countries, which enable eligible people living in an agreement country to apply for certain payments, such as the Age Pension, from that country.
The Australian Government has no plans to change these rules at this time.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Social Services, Ms Rishworth
Pensions and Benefits
Dear Chair
Thank you for the notice of a petition referral (petition number EN5041) dated 20 June 2023, regarding the partner income test.

Australia's social security system is designed to provide a safety net for people who, for reasons such as age, disability, caring responsibilities or unemployment, are unable to fully support themselves. The Australian Government is committed to a welfare system that supports the most vulnerable, encourages those who are able to work or study, and is sustainable for future generations.

The social security income test uses the gross income of both partners, even if one of the partners does not receive a social security payment. This is based on the principle that couples are able to pool their resources for their mutual benefit. Couples generally share their expenses, such as electricity, gas, internet and water. Accordingly, the income of each member of a couple is assessed for the purposes of the social security income test.

Taking into account the combined gross income and assets of both partners also ensures that different couples with similar (combined) levels of resources receive similar levels of support from the social security system. If a partnered person's income support entitlements were based solely on their own income, this would result in unfair outcomes. For example, a couple where one person earned $80,000 and the other earned no income would receive more income support than another couple who both earned $40,000. In a needs-based social security system, this would not be equitable.

In addition, basing a person's income support entitlements solely on their own income would create the situation where some couples could arrange their affairs so that only one member of a couple earns income—for example, income from investments—with the other member of the couple able to obtain a higher level of support from the social security system than would otherwise be the case.

There are safeguards in the social security system for victims of family, domestic, and sexual violence who are receiving or claiming an income support payment. These provisions outline how family, domestic, and sexual violence should be considered by Services Australia when determining whether a person is a member of a couple for social security purposes.

Services Australia (Centrelink) has social workers who can assist people who are struggling financially. They can provide information or a referral to financial counselling services which are free. The Department of Social Services also provides funding to community organisations to deliver free, voluntary and confidential financial counselling services. Under these services, financial counsellors work with people in financial difficulty to address their financial problems, manage debt and make informed choices about their money in the future.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Social Services, Ms Rishworth
Bureau of Meteorology
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 20 June 2023 concerning EN5060 BOM use of actual thermometer temperatures and publishing of long term data.

The Bureau's methods for gathering, storing, analysing and reporting on weather and climate data have been developed over many decades, in collaboration with international peers and the World Meteorological Organization (WMO). The Bureau's methods have been independently peer reviewed and demonstrated to be sound and fit for purpose.

The Bureau makes four main types of weather and climate data available, to meet a range of different purposes: raw data, quality-controlled data, homogenised data and gridded data. Each of these data types is publicly available and the Bureau does not prescribe or proscribe their use.

Raw data are mostly used for applications that require data to be available in real time. You can see these data on the Bureau's Weather App. Raw data can also be found in field books, which are available via the Australian National Archive.

Quality-controlled data, which exist for a larger range of locations and variables, are suitable for many purposes, such as providing records of observed historical rainfall or temperature data for a particular location, and are used for most standard reporting, such as hottest or coldest days on record. These data are available on the Bureau's website.

Gridded data are derived from observations at individual automatic weather stations. These form the basis for the Bureau's mapping products. The Australian Gridded Climate Data monthly rainfall set is an example. You can access these data on the Bureau's website.

Homogenised data allow historical data to be compared with recent data on a consistent basis. Sets of quality-controlled data from a range of stations representative of a region are homogenised to take into account changes over time in measurement technology and geographical locations of observation.

The Bureau maintains stringent version control of its homogenised data. All revisions are documented, and both the original and the homogenised versions of data are made available on the Bureau's website (www.bom.gov.au/climate/data). This enables third parties to analyse data and make comparisons with the Bureau's work.

In line with the WMO's guidelines for best practice, the Bureau has installed over 700 automatic weather stations (AWS) across Australia. AWS readings are taken more frequently, available instantly, and are generally more precise than manual measurements. The change from glass thermometer to automatic reading does not change the observed temperature measurement, on average, because there is no significant or systematic difference in the diurnal range observed using either method.
Noting the above information, I do not support petition EN5060.
I thank the Committee for bringing this issue to the Australian Government's attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for the Environment and Water, Ms Plibersek
Flags
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your email dated 20 June 2023 regarding petition EN5071, which requests the Australian Government legislate that only flags of Australia be flown from public buildings and government-owned flagpoles in Australia.

Australian Government Flag Protocols encourage the dignified and respectful use of flags within Australia and its territories. The Protocols are based on longstanding practice and policy, and are not a matter of law.

It is a decision for each organisation, including local councils, as to which flags are flown on their premises. The Government encourages all Australians to follow flag protocol, however, there is no proposal to legislate which flags should be flown.

Australian Government buildings fly or display the Australian National Flag when practicable during business hours in accordance with the flag protocol. The Government also respects the Australian Aboriginal Flag and the Torres Strait Islander Flag, and encourages all Australians to fly them along with the Australian National Flag. At times of special significance, this is especially encouraged as a symbol of respect and reconciliation.

There may be cases where the national flag of another nation is flown on an Australian Government premises. For example, the Questacon building in Canberra has flown the Australian National Flag with the Japanese National Flag due to the significant history and relationship between Australia and Japan. Further information about this and the history is available on the Questacon website at www.guestacon.edu.au/science- communication/international-engagement/questacon-and-japan.

There are also circumstances where an Australian Government agency may share a building with other organisations, including representatives from another nation. In these cases it may be appropriate to display the national flag of another nation together with the Australian National Flag.
Thank you for bringing this petition to the Australian Government's attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister for the Public Service, Mr Gorman
Electronic Petitions
Dear Ms Templeman

span.span: Petition EN5076 concerning the submission of petitions from repeat petitioners

p.span: Thank you for your correspondence of 20 June 2023 referring to me for response petition EN5076 relating to the submission of petitions from repeat petitioners. The petition asks the House to 'ignore e-petitions from serial complainants'.

Petitioning of Parliament by citizens has a long history within the Westminster parliamentary tradition. In Australia, petitioning Parliament remains a fundamental right of the citizen. It is the only means by which an individual can directly place grievances before the Parliament.

The rules for the content and form of petitions are set out in the standing orders of the House of Representatives. Relevantly, the standing orders do not prescribe a limit on the number of petitions which may be received from a single petitioner. Petitions may be received by the House on public or individual grievances, provided that they relate to matters over which the House has jurisdiction.

Any changes to the standing orders are a matter for the House as a whole; it is not within the power of the Speaker to make changes. I trust that the Petitions Committee has had the opportunity to consider the petition and may reflect on the matters raised in future inquiries into its procedures.
Thank you for writing to me on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Speaker of the House of Representatives, Mr Dick
Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 20 June 2023 regarding petition EN5080 on the Australian Government's decision to increase maximum dispensing quantities for some medications listed on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS).

The Government's decision to implement this recommendation of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee to increase the amount of medication a patient receives for more than 300 medicines is one that has patient benefit and reducing cost-of-living pressures at its core.

Increasing medicine quantities provided on a single script will deliver significant savings for patients, which is why it is an accepted practice in many comparable jurisdictions around the world. Patients in countries that Australia most commonly compares itself with have similar arrangements in place, where patients can access up to 90 or 100 days of commonly used medicines on a single script, including France, Canada, the United Kingdom, and New Zealand.

Claims of increased risk of overdose and misuse from some of the medicines eligible for 60-day dispensing is unfounded. Only patients with certain chronic medical conditions on stable treatment regimens will be eligible for these increased quantities. The option to prescribe two months' worth of medicine is a clinical decision made by a doctor. In making its recommendations, the PBAC applied the following guidance criteria to identify medicines that should not be listed with higher quantities:
medicines where being able to stockpile large quantities could pose a risk to patient safety (for example: narcotics, paracetamol/codeine, psychostimulants, psycholeptics and psychoanaleptics)
medicines with a requirement for regular monitoring and frequent dose titration

medicines where the drug regimen is associated with management of progressively worsening disease or the symptoms are associated with relapse of disease and the patient is not expected to be stable for the next 12 months
medicines prescribed for short-term management of symptoms in chronic diseases
medicines in the Palliative Care section of the Schedule
medicines where the PBAC has recommended a listing that enables prescribers to prescribe less than six months therapy per prescription.

National medicine shortages will not be exacerbated due to this initiative. Increasing maximum supply to two months will not increase the total volume of supply of these medicines, rather it will space supply intervals further apart as the same patients currently obtaining these medicines monthly, will attend the pharmacy every two months instead. Many people will also benefit from fewer GP visits because they will not be forced to renew a script every six months, resulting in millions of visits to the GP being freed up; reducing waiting lists and making it easier to see a doctor.

Australian pharmacies already do much more than just dispense medicines, and the Government wants our trusted pharmacists to play an even bigger role in the health care of Australians. That is why every dollar saved by the Government through fewer dispensing payments will be re-invested back into community pharmacy, to support these highly trained professionals to deliver expanded services, and better recognise pharmacists' scope of practice. As part of the 2023-24 Budget, the Government has committed to providing opportunities for community pharmacists to step out from behind dispensary and provide clinical services to patients, including:

$654.9 million over four years for Community Pharmacy Programs. This includes increasing the total budget for these programs under the Seventh Community Pharmacy Agreement (7CPA) from $1.2 billion to $1.4 billion to ensure these could continue without any amendment, as well as securing funding for programs to be delivered beyond the 7CPA.

$377.3 million over four years for a nationally consistent Opioid Dependence Treatment Program. This funding is in addition to the dispensing-related remuneration pharmacy owners will receive for these medicines being dispensed under the Section 100 Highly Specialised Drugs Community Access Program. Pharmacy owners are expected to receive $175 to $191 per patient per month under these new arrangements.

$114.1 million over four years for Commonwealth-funded administration of vaccines to those aged five years and over through the National Immunisation Program. Pharmacists will be paid $18.85, with no cost to the patient, per vaccine administered. This is the same amount paid to GPs for a Level A Consultation when delivering the same service—something pharmacy stakeholders have asked successive Governments for. Which vaccines can be administered by pharmacists is determined by state and territory legislation.
$79.5 million over four years to double the total annual budget of the Regional Pharmacy Maintenance Allowance.
The Government continues to consider options to support community pharmacy.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Higher Education
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence of 20 June 2023 regarding Petition EN5085—Increase Research Scholarship Rates for PhD students.
The Australian Government acknowledges the invaluable work PhD students undertake to support and advance Australia's research and knowledge base.

The Government's Research Training Program (RTP) is a stipend scholarship offered, on a calendar year basis, to higher education providers to support living expenses for both domestic and overseas students undertaking research doctorate and research masters degrees, known as higher degrees by research (HDRs). It is not considered as income for employment or employment-related activities, and as such is not linked to any benchmarks such as the National Minimum Wage.

Universities have discretion to award RTP stipend rates within a base and maximum range. In 2023, the full-time base RTP stipend rate is $29,863 and the maximum rate is $46,653. This range acknowledges universities are best placed to determine the stipend rates that will enable them to achieve their research training priorities and meet the needs of students. The stipend rates currently offered by universities vary, and several universities have exercised their discretion to raise their minimum rates in recent years to above the full-time base rate.

It may also interest you to know that the Government is committed to delivering an Australian Universities Accord, a 12-month review of Australia's higher education system which is considering a range of issues including research and research training policy settings.

The Accord Panel has provided its interim report on priority actions, with a final report to be delivered to the Government by December 2023. Further information about the Accord can be found on the Department of Education's website at www.education.gov.au/australian-universities-accord.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Education, Mr Clare
Goods and Services Tax
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence to me, received 20 June 2023, concerning Petition EN5089 on the goods and services tax (GST) threshold for individuals and non-profit organisations.

The Government recognises the special role played by charities in the community and in recognition of this provides a higher threshold for GST registration compared to the threshold for businesses. The $150,000 (of GST turnover) GST registration threshold for not-for-profit organisations is required to achieve a balance between including all not-for-profit organisations in the GST system and avoiding unnecessary compliance costs for such organisations. The same principle applies with the GST turnover of $75,000 registration threshold for businesses. There is no GST threshold for individuals as they are not required to register with the Australian Taxation Office for GST purposes.

A change to the existing registration threshold would amount to a change in the GST base. The GST is levied by the Government on behalf of the states and territories and any change to the GST base or rate requires unanimous support of the states and territories. The revenue from the GST goes to the states and territories and provides a secure source of funding to assist them in providing essential services to the community, such as health and education.
Once again, thank you for taking the time to write.
Yours sincerely
from the Treasurer, Dr Chalmers
Gold Coast Light Rail
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your email of 20 June 2023 regarding Commonwealth Infrastructure Projects—Petition Ministerial Referral (EN5103) on the Gold Coast Light Rail Stage 4 project.

The Australian Government has not made any funding commitment towards Stage 4 of the Gold Coast Light Rail. The Queensland Government and Gold Coast City Council are currently undertaking planning works to assess options on a preferred route and consider the potential impacts on the community, cultural heritage and the environment. Any decision to commit Australian Government funding towards a Stage 4 extension would be informed by the findings of these studies, a detailed business case and assessment by Infrastructure Australia.

Infrastructure Australia is an independent statutory body that advises governments, industry and the community on the investments and reforms needed to deliver better infrastructure for all Australians. As such, the selection of projects for the Infrastructure Priority List is a matter for Infrastructure Australia.

As you are aware, on 1 May 2023, I announced an Independent Strategic Review of the Infrastructure Investment Program to ensure projects funded by the Government represent value for money and deliver lasting benefits for Australians. The Review will be undertaken within 90 days and the reviewers will engage with relevant government and industry stakeholders in relation to the projects being reviewed, including with states, territories and local government.

The Government is maintaining a IO-year $120 billion infrastructure pipeline, whilst working towards ensuring land transport infrastructure projects are genuinely nation-building, economically sustainable and resilient to our changing climate.

Until the outcomes of the Review are known, the Government is not able to pre-empt the recommendations of the Independent Review, but will continue to work closely with the Queensland Government to deliver projects already under construction, and the Government's 2022 election commitments.
Thank you for taking the time to write to me on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government, Ms King
Diabetes
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 20 June 2023 regarding Petition EN5105- a proposal to extend access to subsidised continuous glucose monitoring (CGM) products through the National Diabetes Services Scheme (NOSS) to people with type 2 diabetes.
The Australian Government is committed to supporting Australians with diabetes and their families.

The Government provides considerable financial support to people with diabetes through the subsidy of essential medicines, like insulin, under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) and other diabetes-related products, like blood glucose test strips, through the NDSS.
In 2021-22, PBS expenditure on medicines for diabetes was $804 million and expenditure on products for diabetes supplied through the NDSS was over $196 million.
Since 1 July 2022, all Australians with type 1 diabetes have been able to access subsidised CGM products through the NDSS.

This follows implementation of a $273.1 million election commitment made by the Government to provide an additional 71,000 people with type 1 diabetes access to subsidised CGM products, with an affordable co-payment equivalent to $32.50 per month.

Access arrangements will not change for people already eligible to receive free CGM products under the NDSS (including children and young people aged under 21 with type 1 diabetes, women with type 1 diabetes who are planning for pregnancy, pregnant or immediately post-pregnancy, and people with type 1 diabetes aged 21 and over who have a concession card).

Following implementation of this expansion, the Government will continue to monitor the operation of the scheme. This will inform Government consideration of any further expansion of the scheme to adults with other forms of diabetes.
Further information about the NDSS and CGM products, including detailed eligibility criteria, is available at www.ndss.com.au.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
PETITIONS
Statements

Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): Mr Speaker, each year the House of Representatives receives hundreds of petitions from Australian citizens and residents. If the Petitions Committee finds that a petition meets the requirements as set out in the standing orders, the petition is published on the parliament's website and is presented to the House. Once presented, a petition becomes part of the official record of the House and its terms are included in the Hansard for that day.

In addition to this, the Petitions Committee may also refer a petition to the minister responsible for the matters raised, for a written response. Under the standing orders, a minister is expected to provide the response within 90 days.

Almost all petitions received by the House are referred to a minister for a written response. However, the Petitions Committee is currently seeking feedback on this approach from petitioners and other interested community members.

The introduction of electronic petitioning in 2016 has influenced the volume and nature of petitions received by the House. Given the ease of electronic petitioning, it's not surprising that there has been a significant increase in the number of petitions received in recent years. The total number of petitions presented to the House has jumped from 263 in the 44th Parliament, to 799 in the 45th Parliament, to 1,761 in the last Parliament. So far in this parliament 644 petitions have been presented.
There has also been an increase in the number of petitions received with a very small number of signatures; and more people are choosing to submit multiple petitions.

Mr Speaker, the ministerial referral process is a valuable part of the House petitions system. What we are seeking feedback on is whether petitions with only a small number of signatures should be referred. In our discussions, the committee has considered the benefits of providing ministerial responses to petitioners, as well as the allocation of resources needed to coordinate and prepare a considered written response. We also want to ensure that petitions with a large amount of community support continue to receive responses of substance from the relevant minister, in a timely manner.

As part of its review, the committee has looked at procedures in other Westminster parliaments.
